editorialDecl.p: EEBO-TCP is a partnership between the Universities of Michigan and Oxford and the publisher ProQuest to create accurately transcribed and encoded texts based on the image sets published by ProQuest via their Early English Books Online (EEBO) database (http://eebo.chadwyck.com). The general aim of EEBO-TCP is to encode one copy (usually the first edition) of every monographic English-language title published between 1473 and 1700 available in EEBO.

EEBO-TCP aimed to produce large quantities of textual data within the usual project restraints of time and funding, and therefore chose to create diplomatic transcriptions (as opposed to critical editions) with light-touch, mainly structural encoding based on the Text Encoding Initiative (http://www.tei-c.org).

The EEBO-TCP project was divided into two phases. The 25,363 texts created during Phase 1 of the project have been released into the public domain as of 1 January 2015. Anyone can now take and use these texts for their own purposes, but we respectfully request that due credit and attribution is given to their original source.
Users should be aware of the process of creating the TCP texts, and therefore of any assumptions that can be made about the data.

Text selection was based on the New Cambridge Bibliography of English Literature (NCBEL). If an author (or for an anonymous work, the title) appears in NCBEL, then their works are eligible for inclusion. Selection was intended to range over a wide variety of subject areas, to reflect the true nature of the print record of the period. In general, first editions of a works in English were prioritized, although there are a number of works in other languages, notably Latin and Welsh, included and sometimes a second or later edition of a work was chosen if there was a compelling reason to do so.

Image sets were sent to external keying companies for transcription and basic encoding. Quality assurance was then carried out by editorial teams in Oxford and Michigan. 5% (or 5 pages, whichever is the greater) of each text was proofread for accuracy and those which did not meet QA standards were returned to the keyers to be redone. After proofreading, the encoding was enhanced and/or corrected and characters marked as illegible were corrected where possible up to a limit of 100 instances per text. Any remaining illegibles were encoded as <gap>s. Understanding these processes should make clear that, while the overall quality of TCP data is very good, some errors will remain and some readable characters will be marked as illegible. Users should bear in mind that in all likelihood such instances will never have been looked at by a TCP editor.
The texts were encoded and linked to page images in accordance with level 4 of the TEI in Libraries guidelines.

Copies of the texts have been issued variously as SGML (TCP schema; ASCII text with mnemonic sdata character entities); displayable XML (TCP schema; characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or text strings within braces); or lossless XML (TEI P5, characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or TEI g elements).
Keying and markup guidelines are available at the Text Creation Partnership web site.

div.p: THE Coffee-Houſe Politician; OR, THE JUSTICE Caught in his own TRAP.
A COMEDY. As it is Acted at the Theatre-Royal in Lincoln's-Inn Fields.
LONDON: Printed for J. WATTS, at the Printing-Office in Wild-Court near Lincoln's-Inn Fields. MDCCXXX.

lg.l: IN ancient Greece, the Infant Muſe's School,
Where Vice firſt felt the Pen of Ridicule,
With honeſt Freedom and impartial Blows
The Muſe attack'd each Vice as it aroſe:
No Grandeur could the Mighty Villain ſcreen
From the juſt Satyr of the Comick Scene:
No Titles could the daring Poet cool,
Nor ſave the great Right Honourable Fool.
They ſpar'd not even the Aggreſſor's Name,
And Publick Villany felt Publick Shame.
Long hath this gen'rous Method been diſus'd,
For Vice hath grown too great to be abus'd;
By Pow'r, defended from the Piercing Dart,
It reigns, and triumphs in the Lordly Heart;
While Beaus, and Cits, and Squires, our Scenes afford,
Juſtice preſerves the Rogues who weild the Sword;
All Satyr againſt her Tribunal's quaſh'd,
Nor laſh the Bards, for fear of being laſh'd.
But the Heroick Muſe who ſings To-night,
Through theſe neglected Tracks attempts her Flight:
Vice, cloath'd with Pow'r, ſhe combats with her Pen,
And fearleſs, dares the Lyon in his Den.
Then only Reverence to Pow'r is due,
When Publick Welfare is its only View:
But when the Champions, whom the Publick arm
For their own Good with Pow'r, attempt their Harm,
He ſure muſt meet the general Applauſe,
Who 'gainſt thoſe Traytors fights the Publick Cauſe.
And while theſe Scenes the conſcious Knave diſpleaſe,
Who feels within the Criminal he ſees,
The Uncorrupt and Good muſt ſmile, to find
No Mark for Satyr in his Generous Mind.
RAPE upon Rape! what Author ever choſe
A Name ſo ſure to make the Fair his Foes!
And, Ladies, I can read in all your Faces,
Our Author is not much in your good Graces;
But pray, confeſs, does all this Fury fall,
Becauſe theſe Scenes Rape upon Rape we call?
Or is it—that we have no Rape at all?
Our modern Beaus in Vigour are ſo hearty,
And modern Dames ſo very full of Vartue,
So ſcarce immodeſt Women, Men ſo urging,
A Rape's almoſt as common as a—Virgin.
Oh! may our Youth whoſe Vigour is ſo parlous,
To Italy be wafted with Don Carlos;
There ſhould one Victory but give them Scope,
They would not leave one Maidenhead for the Pope;
Or ſhould ſome new Pope Joan the Chair poſſeſs,
They'd play the Devil with her—Holineſs.
Rape upon Rape ſhould follow Blows on Blows,
And New Rome fall, by what the Old aroſe.
Lucretia ſurely, tho' her Fame has ſounded,
With Ardour for her Country ne'er abounded;
Who ſo abhorr'd, what had her Country founded.
Heatheniſh Wretch! the Pious Chriſtian Wife,
Tho' raviſh'd, ſtill contents herſelf with Life:
So zealous from Self-Murther we refrain,
We live, tho' ſure of raviſhing again.
What need has She of Penance or Repenting,
Who undergoes it all without conſenting?
She ſure, tho' with her Sword Lucretian ſwagger,
Requires a Cordial rather than a Dagger.
But may no fear of Raviſhing affright
The beauteous kind Spectators of To-night;
Safe to your Husbands Arms may you eſcape,
And never know that dreadful thing, a RAPE.

div.head: RAPE upon RAPE; OR, The JUSTICE caught in his own TRAP.
SCENE I.
div.stage: SCENE A Parlour in Politick's Houſe. A Table ſpread with News-Papers. Chairs.

sp.speaker: HILARET.
sp.p: WELL, Cloris, this is a mad Frolick. I am horridly frighted at the Thoughts of throwing my ſelf into the Power of a young Fellow.

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.p: It is natural to us to be frighted at firſt: I was in a little Terror my ſelf on my Wedding-Day, but it went all off before the next Morning; a Husband, like other Bugbears, loſes all his Horror when we once know him thoroughly.

sp.speaker: Hil.
sp.p: But if he ſhould not prove a good Husband—

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.p:
Then you muſt not prove a good Wife—If he keeps a Miſtreſs, do you keep a Gallant; if he
ſtay out with his Friends at a Tavern, do you be merry with your Friends at home.

sp.speaker: Hil.
sp.p: You give fine Advice indeed.

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.p: Upon my Word, Madam, it was ſuch as I followed my ſelf. I had a Rogue of a Husband that robbed me of all I had, and kept a Miſtreſs under my Noſe: but I was even with him: for it hath been ever my Opinion that a Husband, like a Courtier, who is above doing the Duties of his Office, ſhould keep a Deputy.

sp.speaker: Hil.
sp.p: But ſuppoſe you had been in Love with your Husband?

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.p: Why ſo I was, Madam, as long as he deſerved it: but Love, like Fire, naturally goes out when it hath nothing to feed on.

sp.speaker: Hil.
sp.p: Well, if it be poſſible to be aſſured of a Lover's Sincerity, I think I may be aſſured of Conſtant: at leaſt it is adviſeable to perſuade my ſelf of his Truth whom I ſhould Love, tho' he wanted it:—Ah, Cloris! you may as eaſily remove a Rock as a Woman's Paſſion—

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.p: And yet it is very often built on a ſandy Foundation.

sp.speaker: Hil.
sp.p: Love is the ſame, whatever be its Object: We as often like Men for imaginary as real Perfections; we all look through a Priſmatick Glaſs in Love, and whatever Beauties we have once fancied, we never loſe the Opinion of—our Amorous Faith is as implicit as our Religious.

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.p: If I have any Judgment in Mankind, and I am ſure I have had ſome Experince in them, your Paſſion could have been no where better fixed: Capt. Conſtant hath all the Qualities any Woman can deſire. He hath Youth, Beauty, Vigour, Gallantry, Conſtancy, and as Mr. Cowley ſays, a long &c.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.p:
Ay there it goes, tick tack, tick tack, like the Pendulum of a Clock. What Miſchief are you hatching,
hey?—It is impoſſible that two Women ſhould be together without producing Miſchief.

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.p: I always thought a Man and Woman the more likely to produce Miſchief: and yet I think them the properer Company.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.p: I ſuppoſe you will tell my Daughter ſo too.

sp.speaker: Hil.
sp.p: Indeed Papa ſhe need not: for I was always of that Opinion.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.p: You was! but I ſhall prevent your Wiſhes—

sp.speaker: Hil.
sp.p: You may be miſtaken.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.p: I do not believe the Head of Cardinal Fleury can be more perplexed, than mine is with this Girl. To govern your ſelf, is greater than to govern a Kingdom, ſaid an old Philoſopher; and to govern a Woman is greater than to govern twenty Kingdoms.

sp.speaker: Hil.
sp.p: I wiſh you would not perplex your ſelf with Cardinals or Kingdoms, I wiſh you would mind your own Buſineſs, inſtead of the Publick's; dear Papa, don't give your ſelf any more trouble about Don Carlos, unleſs you can get him for a Son-in-Law.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.p: Not if I were a King. I will make you a little ſenſible who Don Carlos is.—

sp.speaker: Hil.
sp.p: Nay, I do not underſtand one Word of your Politicks.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.p: I am ſorry you do not—A News-Paper would be a more profitable Entertainment for you than a Romance. You would find more in one half Sheet, than in the grand Cyrus.

sp.speaker: Hil.
sp.p: More Lies very probably—You know I do read the Home Paragraphs in the Whitehail Evening Poſt: and that's the beſt of them.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.p: If you would be informed in theſe Matters, you muſt read all that come out: about forty every Day, and ſome Days fifty: and of a Saturday about fourſcore. Would you continue in ſuch a Courſe but one Twelvemonth, I do not queſtion but you might know as much of Politicks as—any Man that comes to our Coffee-houſe. And I had rather ſee you a Politician, than a Woman of Quality.

sp.speaker: Hil.
sp.p: If I may ſpeak freely, it would have been better for me that you had been leſs a Politician.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.p: You are deceived, very much deceived: but ſome Fool hath put this into your Head. You may live to ſee me one of the greateſt Men in England. Did I not ſay at the Siege of Gibraltar, that within one three Years, we ſhould ſee whether we ſhould have Peace or no. And yet I am an Ignoramus; I know nothing I warrant you: I had better have continued a Merchant no doubt: but then what had become of my Projects? where had been all thoſe twenty different Schemes which I have now ready to lay before the Parliament, greatly for my own Honour and the Intereſt of my Country? Harkye, I have contrived a Method to pay off the Debts of the Nation, without a Penny of Money.

sp.speaker: Hil.
sp.p: And you will not get a Penny by it, I dare ſwear.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.p: No, no, no certainly: tho' I would not take twenty thouſand Pounds for the Advantage which will ariſe to me from it. It hath lain theſe three Years in a Friend's Hands of mine of the Houſe of Commons; who aſſured me not many Days ago that it ſhould be taken ſhortly into Conſideration, tho' he believed it could not be this Seſſions.

sp.speaker: Hil.
sp.p: Nor this Age, I am confident.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.p: And how do you think it is to be compaſſed! why, by procuring a Machine to carry Ships by Land about a hundred Miles: and ſo proſecute the Eaſt-India Trade, thro' the Mediterranean.

sp.speaker: Hil.
sp.p: I wiſh you Succeſs, Sir: but I muſt take my leave of you, for it grows very late: ſo good-Night, Papa.

I cannot reſt for theſe Preparations of the Turks. what can be their Deſign!—It muſt be againſt the Emperor.—Ay, ay, we ſhall have another Campaign in Hungary. I wiſh we may feel no other
effect from them—ſhould the Turkiſh Gallies once find a Paſſage through the Straights, who can tell the Conſequence. I hope I ſhall not live to ſee that Day

div.head: SCENE IV.

sp.speaker: Dab.
sp.p: We are all undone, Neighbour Politick! all blown up! all ruined!

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.p: Protect us—what is the Matter? No News of the Turks, I hope!

sp.speaker: Dab.
sp.p: An Expreſs is arrived with an Account of the Dauphin's Death.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.p: Worſe and worſe—this is a finiſhing Stroke indeed! Mr. Dabble, I take this Viſit exceeding kind—pray be pleaſed to ſit: we muſt confabulate on this Important Accident.—Pray light your Pipe—I wiſh this may not retard the Introduction of Don Carlos into Italy.

sp.speaker: Dab.
sp.p: I wiſh it may.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.p: How!

sp.speaker: Dab.
sp.p: I wiſh Don Carlos do not prove a more formidable Power than is imagined.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.p: Don Carlos a formidable Power, Mr. Dabble?

sp.speaker: Dab.
sp.p: I wiſh we do not find him ſo.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.p: Sir, I look on Don Carlos to be an errant Blank in the Affairs of Europe—and let me obſerve to you, the Turks give me much greater Uneaſineſs than Don Carlos can: What the deſign of their Preparations can be, is difficult to determine—this I know, that I know nothing of the matter.

sp.speaker: Dab.
sp.p: I think we have no need to travel ſo far for Apprehenſions, when Danger is ſo near us: the Proſpect of Affairs in the Weſt is ſo black, that I ſee no Reaſon to regard the Eaſt: the monſtrous Power which Don Carlos may be poſſeſſed of by the Death of the Dauphin—

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.p: Rather, the monſtrous Power which the Emperor may be poſſeſſed of.

sp.speaker: Dab.
sp.p: The Emperor—ah!—

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.p: Don Carlos truly.

div.stage: Both ſhake their Heads at one another.

sp.speaker: Dab.
sp.p: I would fain ask one Queſtion, Mr. Politick. Prav how large do you take Tuſcany to be?—

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.p: How large do I take Tuſcany to be—let me ſee—Tuſcany, ay; how large do I take it to be—hum—Faithful!—bring ſome more Tobacco. How large do I take it to be—why truly I take it to be about as large as the Kingdom of France—or ſomething larger.—

sp.speaker: Dab.
sp.p: As large as the Kingdom of France—you might as well compare this Tobacco-Pipe to a Canon. Why Tuſcany, Sir, is only a Town, a Garriſon to be admitted into Tuſcany; that is, into the Town of Tuſcany—

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.p: Sir, I will convince you of your Error—here, Faithful, bring a Map of Europe hither

sp.speaker: Dab.
sp.p: I did not think, Mr. Politick, you had been ſo ignorant in Geography.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.p: Sir, I believe I know as much as you, or any one, of it.

sp.speaker: Faith
sp.p: Sir, Sir, your Daughter is gone out of the Houſe, no one knows whither.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.p: And give me leave to tell you, Sir, I wiſh your own Ignorance in publick Affairs doth not appear to our Coſt.

sp.speaker: Dab.
sp.p: Sir, I wiſh you would ſend for the Map.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.p: Map me no Maps, Sir, my Head is a Map, a Map of the whole World.—

sp.speaker: Faith.
sp.p: Sir, your Daughter—

sp.speaker: Dab.
sp.p: If your Head be a Map, it is a very erroneous one.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.p: Sir, I would not have called Tuſcany a Town in a Coffee-Houſe, to have been Maſter of it.

sp.speaker: Dab.
sp.p: Nor I have compared it to France, to have been King of both.

sp.speaker: Por.
sp.p: Great News, Gentlemen, all's ſafe again.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.p: More Deaths?

sp.speaker: Por.
sp.p: An Expreſs is arrived with a certain Account of the Dauphin's being in good Health.

sp.speaker: Dab.
sp.p: This is good News indeed.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.p: Is there a certain Confirmation?

sp.speaker: Por.
sp.p: Very certain—I came this moment from the Secretary's Office.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.p: Dear Mr. Porer, you are the welcomeſt Man alive—This News makes me the happieſt Creature living.

sp.speaker: Faith.
sp.p: I wiſh, Sir, my News may not prevent it—Your Daughter, Sir, Miſs Hilaret, is gone out of the Houſe, and no one knows whither▪

sp.speaker: Pol
sp.p: My Daughter gone! that is ſome allay to my Happineſs, I confeſs: but the loſs of twenty Daughters would not balance the Recovery of the Dauphin—However, Gentlemen, you will excuſe me, I muſt go enquire into this Affair.

sp.speaker: Dab.
sp.p: Be not concerned at any thing, after what you have heard: let the Priva • e give way to the Publick ever.

sp.speaker: Sotm.
sp.p: Why, thou wilt not leave us yet, and ſneak away to ſome naſty little Whore? A Pox confound them, they have ſpoiled ſo many of my Companions, and forced me to Bed ſober at three-a-Clock in the Morning ſo often—that if the whole Sex were going to the Devil, I would drink a Bumper to their good Journey.

sp.speaker: Ram.
sp.p: And I would go thither along with them. The dear charming Creatures! Woman! It is the beſt Word that ever was invented. There's Muſick, there's Magick in it. Mark Anthony knew well to lay out his Money, and when he gave the World for a Woman—he bought a lumping Pennyworth.

sp.speaker: Sot.
sp.p: If he had given it for a Hogſhead of good Claret, I would have commended the Purchaſe more.

sp.speaker: Ramb.
sp.p: Wine is only the Prologue to Love: it only ſerves to raiſe our Expectation. The Bottle is but a Paſsport to the Bed of Pleaſure. Brutes drink to quench their Appetites—but Lovers to enflame them.

sp.speaker: Sot.
sp.p: 'Tis Pity the generous Liquor ſhould be uſed to no better a Purpoſe.

sp.speaker: Ramb.
sp.p: It is the nobleſt uſe of the Grape, and the greateſt Glory of Bacchus is to be Page to Venus.

sp.speaker: Sot.
sp.p: Before I go into a Tavern again with a Man who will ſneak away after the firſt Bottle, may I be curſed with the odious ſight of a Pint as long as I live: or become Member of a City-Club where Men drink out of Thimbles, that the Fancy may be heightened by the Wine, about the ſame time that the Underſtanding is improved by the Converſation: I'll ſooner drink Coffee with a Politician, Tea with a fine Lady, or 'Rack Punch with a fine Gentleman, than thus be made a Whetſtone of, to ſharpen my Friends Inclinations, that ſome little Strumpet may enjoy the Benefit of that good Humour which I have raiſed.

sp.speaker: Ramb.
sp.p: Why, thou art as ill-natured and as angry as a Woman would be, who was diſappointed in the laſt Moment, when her Expectations were at the higheſt.

sp.speaker: Sot.
sp.p: And have I not the ſame Cauſe?

sp.speaker: Ramb.
sp.p: Truly, honeſt Nol, when a Man's Reaſon begins to ſtagger, I think him the propereſt Company for the Women: One Bottle more, and I had been fit for no Company at all.

sp.speaker: Sot.
sp.p: Then thou hadſt been carried off with Glory.—An honeſt Fellow ſhould no more quit the Tavern while he can ſtand, than a Soldier ſhould the Field; but you fine Gentlemen are for preſerving your ſelves ſafe from both, for the Benefit of the Ladies.—'Sdeath! I'll uſe you with the ſame Scorn that a Soldier would a Coward: So, Sir, when I meet you next, be not ſurprized if I walk on the other ſide the way.

sp.speaker: Ramb.
sp.p:
Nay, pr'ythee, dear Silenus, be not ſo enraged; I'll but take one refreſhing turn, and come
back to the Tavern to thee. Burgundy ſhall be the Word, and I will fight under thy Command till I drop.

sp.speaker: Sot.
sp.p: Now thou art an honeſt Fellow—and thou ſhalt Toaſt whomſoever thou pleaſeſt.—We'll bumper up her Health, till thou doſt enjoy her in Imagination. To a warm Imagination there is no Bawd like a Bottle. It ſhall throw into your Arms, the ſobereſt Prude or wildeſt Coquet in Town; thou ſhalt rifle her Charms, in ſpight of her Art. Nay, thou ſhalt encreaſe her Charms more than her Art: and when thou art ſurfeited with the luſcious Pleaſure, wake cooly the next Morning, without any Wife by your ſide, or any fear of Children.

sp.speaker: Ramb.
sp.p: What a luſcious Picture haſt thou drawn!

sp.speaker: Sot.
sp.p: And thou ſhalt have it, Boy! thou ſhalt triumph over her Virtue, if ſhe be a Woman of Quality—or raiſe her Bluſhes, if ſhe be a common Strumpet. I'll go order a new Recruit upon the Table, and expect you with Impatience—Fill every Glaſs.

sp.speaker: Ramb.
sp.p: Sure, this Fellow's whole Senſation lies in his Throat: for he is never pleaſed but when he is ſwallowing: And yet the Hogſhead will be as ſoon drunk with the Liquor it contains, as he. I wiſh it had no other Effect upon me. Pox of my Paper Scull! I have no ſooner buried the Wine in my Belly, than its Spirit riſes in my Head—I am in a very proper Humour for a Frolick; If my good Genius, and her evil one would but ſend ſome lovely Female in my way—Ha! the Devil hath heard my Prayers.

sp.speaker: Hil.
sp.p: Was ever any thing ſo unfortunate! to loſe this Wench in the Scuffle, and not know a ſtep of the Way—What ſhall I do?

sp.speaker: Ramb.
sp.p: By all my love of Glory, an Adventure.

sp.speaker: Hil
sp.p: Ha! who's that? who are you, Sir?

sp.speaker: Ramb
sp.p: A Cavalier, Madam, a Knight Er • ant rambling about the World in queſt of Adventures. To plunder Widows, and raviſh Virgins; to leſſen the Number of Bullies, and encreaſe that of Cuckolds, are the Obligations of my Profeſſion.

sp.speaker: Hil.
sp.p: I wiſh you all the Succeſs ſo worthy an Adventurer deſerves.

sp.speaker: Ramb.
sp.p: But hold, Madam, I am but juſt ſallied, and you are the firſt Adventure I have met with.

sp.speaker: Hil.
sp.p: Let me go I beſeech you, Sir, I will have nothing to ſay to any of your Profeſſion.

sp.speaker: Ramb.
sp.p: That's unkind, Madam: for as I take it, our Profeſſions are pretty nearly allied, and like Prieſt and Nun, we are proper Company for one another.

sp.speaker: Hil.
sp.p: My Profeſſion, Sir!

sp.speaker: Ramb.
sp.p: Yes, Madam, I believe I am no Stranger to the honourable Rules of your Order. Nay, 'tis probable I may know your Abbeſs too; for tho' I have not been in Town a Week, I am acquainted with half a Dozen.

sp.speaker: Hil.
sp.p: Nothing but your Drink, Sir, and Ignorance of my Quality, could excuſe this Rudeneſs.

sp.speaker: Ramb.
sp.p: (Whu— [whiſtles] Ignorance of your Quality! The Daughter of ſome Perſon of Rank, I warrant her) [Aſide] Look'e, my Dear, I ſhall not trouble my ſelf with your Quality: It is equal to me, whether your Father rode in a Coach and Six, or drove it—I have had as much Joy in the Arms of an honeſt Boatſwain's Wife, as with a Relation of the Great Mogul.

sp.speaker: Hil.
sp.p: You look, Sir, ſo much like a Gentleman, that I am perſuaded this Uſage proceeds only from your miſtaking me. I own it looks a little odd for a Woman of Virtue to be found alone in the Street, at this Hour—

sp.speaker: Ramb.
sp.p: Yes it does look a little odd indeed.

sp.speaker: Hil.
sp.p: But when you know my Story, I am confident you will aſſiſt me, rather than otherwiſe. I have this very Night eſcaped with my Maid from my Father's Houſe; and as I was going to put my ſelf into the Hands of my Lover, a Scuffle happening in the Street, and both running away in a Fright to avoid it, we unluckily ſeparated from each other—Now, Sir, I relie on the Generoſity of your Temper to aſſiſt an unhappy Woman, for which you ſhall not only have my Thanks, but thoſe of a very pretty Fellow into the Bargain.

sp.speaker: Ramb.
sp.p: I am that very pretty Fellow's very humble Servant. But I find I am too much in Love with you my ſelf, to preſerve you for another: Had you proved what I at firſt took you for, I ſhould have parted with you eaſily; but I read a Coronet in your Eyes: (ſhe ſhall be her Grace if ſhe pleaſes, I had rather give her a Title than Money)

sp.speaker: Hil.
sp.p: Nay, now you miſtake me as widely as you did at firſt.

sp.speaker: Ramb.
sp.p: Nay, by this Frolick, Madam, you muſt be either a Woman of Quality, or a Woman of the Town—Your low mean People, who govern themſelves by Rules, dare not attempt theſe noble Flights of Pleaſure. Flights only to be reached by thoſe who boldly ſoar above Reputation.

sp.speaker: Hil.
sp.p: This is the maddeſt Fellow.

sp.speaker: Ramb.
sp.p: So, my Dear, whether you be of Quality or no Quality, you and I will go drink one Bottle together at the next Tavern.

sp.speaker: Hil.
sp.p: I have but one Way to get rid of him.

sp.speaker: Ramb.
sp.p: Come, my dear Angel. Oh! this dear ſoft Hand.

sp.speaker: Hil.
sp.p: Could I but be aſſur'd that my Virtue would be ſafe.

sp.speaker: Ramb.
sp.p: No where ſafer. I'll give thee any thing in Pawn for it—(but my Watch)

sp.speaker: Hil.
sp.p: And then my Reputation—

sp.speaker: Ramb.
sp.p: The Night will take Care of that—Virtue and Reputation! theſe Whores have learnt a ſtrange Cant ſince I left England.

sp.speaker: Hil.
sp.p: But will you love me always?

sp.speaker: Ramb.
sp.p: Oh! for ever and ever, to be ſure.

sp.speaker: Hil.
sp.p: But will you—too.

sp.speaker: Ramb.
sp.p: Yes, I will—too.

sp.speaker: Hil.
sp.p: Will you promiſe to be civil?

sp.speaker: Ramb.
sp.p: Oh! yes, yes; (I was afraid ſhe would have asked me for Money.)

sp.speaker: Hil.
sp.p: Well, then I will venture—Go you to that corner Tavern, I'll follow you.

sp.speaker: Ramb.
sp.p: Excuſe me, Madam, I know my Duty better—ſo if you pleaſe, I'll follow you.

sp.speaker: Hil.
sp.p: I inſiſt on your going firſt.

sp.speaker: Ramb.
sp.p: And ſo you'll leave me in the Lurch: I ſee you are frighted at the Roughneſs of my Dreſs; but foregad I am an honeſt Tar, and the Devil take me if I bilk you.

sp.speaker: Hil.
sp.p: I don't underſtand you.

sp.speaker: Ramb.
sp.p: Why then, Madam, here is a Pound of as good Tea as ever came out of the Indies; you underſtand that, I hope.

sp.speaker: Hil.
sp.p: I ſhall take no Bribes, Sir.

sp.speaker: Ramb.
sp.p: Refuſe the Tea! I like you now indeed; for you cannot have been long upon the Town, I'm ſure. But I grow weary with Impatience. If you are a modeſt Woman, and inſiſt on the Ceremony of being carried, with all my Heart.

sp.speaker: Hil.
sp.p: Nay, Sir, do not proceed to Rudeneſs.

sp.speaker: Ramb.
sp.p: In ſhort, my Paſſion will be dallied with no longer. Do you conſider, I am juſt come on Shore, that I have ſeen nothing but Men and the Clouds this half Year, and a Woman is as raviſhing a Sight to me as the returning Sun to Greenland. I am none of your puiſny Beaux, that can look on a fine Woman, like a ſurfeited Man on an Entertainment. My Stomach's ſharp, and you are an Ortelan; and if I do not eat you up, may ſalt Beef be my Fare for ever.

sp.speaker: Hil.
sp.p: I'll alarm the Watch.

sp.speaker: Ramb.
sp.p:
You'll be better natur'd than that. At leaſt. to encounter Danger is my Profeſſion; ſo have at you,
my little Venus—If you don't conſent, Ill raviſh you.

sp.speaker: Hil.
sp.p: Help there! a Rape, a Rape!

sp.speaker: Ramb.
sp.p: Huſh, huſh, you call too loud, People will think you are in earneſt.

sp.speaker: Hil.
sp.p: Help, a Rape!—

sp.speaker: Staff.
sp.p: That's he there, ſeize him.

sp.speaker: Ramb.
sp.p: Stand off, ye Scoundrels!

sp.speaker: Staff.
sp.p: Ay, Sir, you ſhould have ſtood off—Do you charge this Man with a Rape, Madam?

sp.speaker: Hil.
sp.p: I am frighted out of my Senſes—

sp.speaker: Staff.
sp.p: A plain Caſe!—the Rape is ſufficiently proved—what, was the Devil in you, to raviſh a Woman in the Street thus?

sp.speaker: Hil.
sp.p: Oh! dear Mr. Conſtable, all I deſire is, that you would ſee me ſafe home.

sp.speaker: Staff.
sp.p: Never fear, Madam, you ſhall not want Evidence.

sp.speaker: Ramb.
sp.p: (Nay, if I muſt lodge with theſe Gentlemen, I am reſolved to have your Company, Madam.) Mr. Conſtable, I charge that Lady with threatning to ſwear a Rape againſt me, and laying violent Hands upon my Perſon, whilſt I was inoffenſively walking along the Street.

sp.speaker: Hil.
sp.p: How! Villain!

sp.speaker: Ramb.
sp.p: Ay, ay, Madam, you ſhall be made a ſevere Example of. The Laws are come to a fine Paſs truly, when a Sober Gentleman can't walk the Streets for Women.

sp.speaker: Hil.
sp.p: For Heaven's ſake, Sir, don't believe him.

sp.speaker: Staff.
sp.p: Nay, Madam, as we have but your bare Affirmation on both Sides, we cannot tell which Way to incline our Belief; that will be determin'd in the Morning by your Characters.—I would not have you dejected, you ſhall not want a Character.

sp.speaker: Hil.
sp.p: This was the moſt unfortunate Accident ſure, that ever befel a Woman of Virtue.

sp.speaker: Staff.
sp.p: If you are a Woman of Virtue, the Gentleman will be hanged for attempting to rob you of it. If you are not a Woman of Virtue, why you will be whipped for accuſing a Gentleman of robbing you of what you had not to loſe.

sp.speaker: Hil.
sp.p: Oh! this unfortunate Fright!—But, Mr. Conſtaſtable, I am very willing that the Gentleman ſhould have his Liberty, give me but mine.

sp.speaker: Staff.
sp.p: That Requeſt, Madam, is a very colloborating Circumſtance againſt you.

sp.speaker: Ramb.
sp.p: Guilt will ever diſcover it ſelf.

sp.speaker: Staff.
sp.p: Bring them along▪

sp.speaker: 1Watch.
sp.p: She looks like a modeſt Woman, in my Opinion.

sp.speaker: Ramb.
sp.p: Confound all your modeſt Women, I ſay—a Man can have nothing to do with a modeſt Woman, but he muſt be married, or hanged for't.

div.head: SCENE I.
div.stage: SCENE Juſtice Squeezum's; a Table, Pen Ink, Paper, &c.

sp.speaker: Squeez.
sp.p: DID Mother Bilkum refuſe to pay my Demands, ſay you?

sp.speaker: Quill.
sp.p: Yes, Sir; ſhe ſays ſhe does not value your Worſhip's Protection of a Farthing, for that ſhe can bribe two Juries a Year to acquit her in Hicks's-Hall, for half the Money which ſhe hath paid you within theſe three Months.

sp.speaker: Squeez.
sp.p:
Very fine! I ſhall ſhew her that I underſtand ſomething of Juries, as well as her ſelf. Quill, make a Memorandum againſt Mother Bilkum's Trial, that we
may remember to have the Pannel No 3. they are a Set of good Men and true, and hearken to no Evidence but mine.

sp.speaker: Quill.
sp.p: Sir, Mr. Snap the Bailiff's Follower hath ſet up a Shop, and is a Freeholder. He hopes your Worſhip will put him into a Pannel on the firſt Vacancy.

sp.speaker: Squeez.
sp.p: Minute him down for No 2. I think half of that Pannel are Bailiffs Followers. Thank Heaven, the Laws have not excluded thoſe Butchers—

sp.speaker: Quill.
sp.p: No, Sir, the Law forbids Butchers to be Jurymen, but does not forbid Jurymen to be Butchers.

sp.speaker: Squeez.
sp.p: Quill, d'ee hear! look out for ſome new Recruits for the Pannel No 1. We ſhall have a ſwinging Vacancy there the next Seſſions.—Truly, if we do not take ſome care to regulate the Juries in the Old-Baily, we ſhall have no Juries for Hicks's-Hall.

sp.speaker: Quill.
sp.p: Very true, Sir. But that Pannel hath been more particularly unfortunate. I believe I remember it hanged, at leaſt twice over.

sp.speaker: Squeez.
sp.p: Ay, poor Fellows! We muſt all take our Chance, Quill. The Man who would live in this World, muſt not fear the next. The Chance of Peace is d • ubtful as that of War; and they who will make their Fortunes at Home, ſhould entertain no more Dread of the Bench, than a Soldier ſhould of the Field. We are all militant here, and a Halter hath been fatal to many a great Man, as well as a Bullet.

sp.speaker: Quill.
sp.p: Sir, here's Mr. Staff, the Reforming Conſtable.

sp.speaker: Staff.
sp.p: An't pleaſe your Worſhip, we have been at the Gaming-Houſe in the Alley, and have taken Six Priſoners, whereof we diſcharged two who had your Worſhip's Licenſe.

sp.speaker: Squeez.
sp.p: What are the others?

sp.speaker: Staff.
sp.p:
One is an Half-pay Officer; another an Attorney's
Clerk; and the other two are young Gentlemen of the Temple.

sp.speaker: Squeez.
sp.p: Diſcharge the Officer and the Clerk, there is nothing to be got by the Army or the Law; the one hath no Money, and the other will part with none. But be not too forward to quit the Templers.

sp.speaker: Staff.
sp.p: Asking your Worſhip's Pardon, I don't care to run my Finger into the Lion's Mouth. I would not willingly have to do with any Limb of the Law.

sp.speaker: Squeez.
sp.p: Fear not; theſe bear no nearer Affinity to Lawyers, than a Militia Regiment of Squires do to Soldiers; the one gets no more by his Gown, than the other by his Sword. Theſe are Men that bring Eſtates to the Temple, inſtead of getting them there.

sp.speaker: Staff.
sp.p: Nay, they are bedawb'd with Lace as fine as Lords.

sp.speaker: Squeez.
sp.p: Never fear a Lawyer in Lace—the Lawyer that ſets out in Lace, always ends in Rags.

sp.speaker: Staff.
sp.p: I'll ſecure them.—We went to the Houſe where your Worſhip commanded us, and heard the Dice into the Street, but there were two Coaches with Coronets on them at the Door, ſo we thought it proper not to go in.

sp.speaker: Squeez.
sp.p: You did right. The Laws are Turnpikes, only made to ſtop People who walk on Foot, and not to interrupt thoſe who drive through them in their Coaches.—The Laws are like a Game at Loo, where a Blaze of Court Cards is always ſecure, and the Knaves are the ſafeſt Cards in the Pack.

sp.speaker: Staff.
sp.p: We have taken up a Man for a Rape too.

sp.speaker: Squeez.
sp.p: What is he?

sp.speaker: Staff.
sp.p: I fancy he's ſome great Man; for he talks French, ſings Italian, and ſwears Engliſh.

sp.speaker: Squeez.
sp.p: Is he rich?

sp.speaker: Staff.
sp.p: I believe not, for we can't get a Farthing out of him.

sp.speaker: Squeez.
sp.p: A certain Sign that he is. Deep Pockets are like deep Streams; and Money, like Water, never runs faſter than in the Shallows.

sp.speaker: Staff.
sp.p: Then there's another Misfortune too.

sp.speaker: Squeez.
sp.p: What's that?

sp.speaker: Staff.
sp.p: The Woman will not ſwear any thing againſt him.

sp.speaker: Squeez.
sp.p: Never fear that, I'll make her ſwear enough for my Purpoſe. What ſort of a Woman is ſhe?

sp.speaker: Staff.
sp.p: A common Whore, I believe.

sp.speaker: Squeez.
sp.p: The propereſt Perſon in the World to ſwear a Rape. A modeſt Woman is as ſhy of ſwearing a Rape, as a Gentleman is of ſwearing a Battery.—We will make her ſwear enough to frighten him into a Compoſition, a ſmall Part of which will ſatisfie the Woman. So go bring them before me.—But hold! have you been at home ſince I ſent a Priſoner thither this Morning?

sp.speaker: Staff.
sp.p: Yes, an't pleaſe your Worſhip.

sp.speaker: Squeez.
sp.p: And what ſays he?

sp.speaker: Staff.
sp.p: He threatens us confoundedly; and ſays you have committed him without any Accuſation. I'm afraid we ſhall get nothing out of him.

sp.speaker: Squeez.
sp.p: We'll try him till Noon, however.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Squeez.
sp.p: I deſire, Mr. Squeezum, you would finiſh all your dirty Work this Morning, for I am reſolved to have the Houſe to my ſelf in the Afternoon.

sp.speaker: Squeez.
sp.p: You ſhall, my Dear; and I ſhall be obliged to you, if you can let me have the Coach this Morning.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Squeez.
sp.p: I ſhall uſe it my ſelf.

sp.speaker: Squeez.
sp.p: Then I muſt get Horſes put into the Chariot.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Squeez.
sp.p: I am not determined whether I ſhall uſe the Coach or Chariot, ſo it is impoſſible you ſhould have either. Beſides, a Hack is the propereſt to do Buſineſs in, and as I cannot ſpare you a Servant, will look better.

sp.speaker: Squeez.
sp.p:
Well, Child, well, it ſhall be ſo.—Let
me only beg the Favour of Dining a little ſooner than ordinary.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Squeez.
sp.p: That is ſo far from being poſſible, that we cannot Dine 'till an Hour later than uſual, becauſe I muſt attend at an Auction, or I ſhall loſe a little China Baſin which is worth its Weight in Jewels, and it is probable I may get it for its Weight in Gold, which will not be above One Hundred Guineas, and thoſe you muſt give me, Child.

sp.speaker: Squeez.
sp.p: A Hundred Guineas for a China Baſon! Oh the Devil take the Eaſt-India Trade! The Clay of the one Indies runs away with all the Gold of the other.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Squeez.
sp.p: I may buy it for leſs; but it is good to have rather too much Money about one, than too little.

sp.speaker: Squeez.
sp.p: In ſhort, I cannot ſupport your Extravagance.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Squeez.
sp.p: I do not deſire you to ſupport my Extravagance.

sp.speaker: Squeez.
sp.p: I wiſh you would not.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Squeez.
sp.p: Thus ſtands the Caſe: You ſay I am extravagant; I ſay, I am not; ſure, my Word will ballance yours every where but at Hicks's-Hall.—And heark'e, my Dear, if whenever I ask for a Trifle, you object my Extravagance to me, I'll be reveng'd, I'll blow you up, I'll diſcover all your midnight Intrigues, your protecting Ill Houſes, your bribing Juries, your ſnacking Fees, your whole Train of Rogueries. If you do not allow me what I ask, I'll bid fair to enter on my Jointure, Sir.

sp.speaker: Squeez.
sp.p: Well, my Dear, this Time you ſhall be indulged.—Truſt a Thief or Lawyer with your Purſe▪ a Whore or Phyſician with your Conſtitution, bu • never truſt a dangerous Secret with your Wife; fo • when once you have put it into her Power to hang you, the ſooner you are hang'd, the better.

div.head: SCENE IV.
div.stage: Squeezum, Quill, Mrs. Squeezum, Staff, Watch, Ramble, Hilaret.

sp.speaker: Staff.
sp.p: An't pleaſe your Worſhip, here is a Gentleman hath committed a Rape laſt Night on this young Woman.

sp.speaker: Squeez.
sp.p: How! a Rape! Hath he committed a Rape on you, Child?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Squeez.
sp.p: This may be worth hearing.

sp.speaker: Hil.
sp.p: Sir, I have nothing to ſay againſt him. I deſire you would give us both our Liberty. He was a little frolickſome laſt Night, which made me call for theſe People's Help, and when once they had taken hold of us, they would not ſuffer us to go away.

sp.speaker: Squeez.
sp.p: They did their Duty.—The Power of Diſcharging lieth in us, and not in them.

sp.speaker: Ramb.
sp.p: Sir—

sp.speaker: Squeez.
sp.p: Sir, I beg we may not be interrupted. Heark'e, young Woman, if this Gentleman hath treated you in an ill manner, do not let your Modeſty prevent the Execution of Juſtice. Conſider, you will be guilty your ſelf of the next Offence he commits; and upon my Word, by his Looks, it is probable he may commit a Dozen Rapes within this Week.

sp.speaker: Hil.
sp.p: Sir, I aſſure you he is innocent.

sp.speaker: Squeez.
sp.p: Mr. Staff, what ſay you to this Affair?

sp.speaker: Staff.
sp.p: May it pleaſe your Worſhip, I ſaw the Priſoner behave in a very indecent manner, and heard the Woman ſay he had raviſhed away her Senſes.

sp.speaker: Squeez.
sp.p: Fye upon you, Child, will you not ſwear this?

sp.speaker: Hil.
sp.p: No, Sir; but I ſhall ſwear ſomething againſt you, unleſs you diſcharge us.

sp.speaker: Squeez.
sp.p: That cannot be, Madam, the Fact is too plain. If you will not ſwear now, the Priſoner muſt be kept in Cuſtody 'till you will.

sp.speaker: Staff.
sp.p: If ſhe will not ſwear, we can ſwear enough to convict him.

sp.speaker: Ramb.
sp.p: Very fine, faith! this Juſtice is worſe than a Grand Inquiſitor. Pray, honeſt, formidable Sir, what private Pique have you againſt me, that you would compel the Lady to deſerve the Pillory, in order to promote me higher?

sp.speaker: Squeez.
sp.p: My Dear, did you ever ſee ſuch a raviſhing Look as this Fellow hath! Sir, if I was a Judge I would hang you without any Evidence at all. They are ſuch Fellows as theſe who ſow Diſſention between Man and Wife, and keep up the Names of Cuckold and Baſtard in the Kingdom.

sp.speaker: Ramb.
sp.p: Nay, if that be all you accuſe me of, I will confeſs it freely, I have employ'd my Time pretty well: Tho' as I do not remember ever to have done you the Honour of Dubbing, Mr. Juſtice, I cannot ſee why you ſhould be ſo incenſed againſt me; for I do not imagine you any otherwiſe an Enemy to theſe Amuſements, than a Popiſh Prieſt to Sin, or a Doctor to Diſeaſe.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Squeez.
sp.p: You are very civil, Sir, to threaten to dub my Husband before my Face.

sp.speaker: Ramb.
sp.p: I ask Pardon, Madam; I did not know with whom I had the Honour to be in Company; it was always againſt my Inclination to affront a Lady; but a Woman of your particular Merit, muſt have claimed the moſt particular Reſpect.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Squeez.
sp.p: I ſhould have expected no Rudeneſs from a Gentleman of your Appearance, and would much rather attribute any misbecoming Word to Inadvertency, than Deſign.

sp.speaker: Ramb.
sp.p: Madam, I know not how to thank ſo much Goodneſs; but do aſſure you, I would buy an Introduction to your Acquaintance at a much greater Danger than this Proſecution, which, I believe, you already ſee the Malice of. I hope, Madam, I ſtand already acquitted in your Opinion.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Squeez.
sp.p: I hope, Sir, it will only appear to have been a Frolick: I muſt own I have been always a great Enemy to Force—ſince there are ſo many willing.

sp.speaker: Ramb.
sp.p: So, I find there is no danger of a Rape here.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Squeez.
sp.p: Well, Child, can you find any thing againſt this Gentleman?

sp.speaker: Squeez.
sp.p: The Woman is difficult of confeſſing in publick: but I fancy when I examine her in private I may get it out of her—So, Mr. Conſtable, withdraw your Priſoner.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Squeez.
sp.p: Nay he appears ſo much of a Gentleman, that till there be ſtronger Evidence, I will take Charge of him—Come, Sir, you ſhall go drink a diſh of Tea with me—You may ſtay without.

sp.speaker: Ramb.
sp.p: This Kindneſs of yours, Madam, will be an Encouragement to Offenders.

sp.speaker: Squeez.
sp.p: Come, come, Child, you had better take the Oath, tho' you are not altogether ſo ſure. Juſtice ſhould be rigorous. It is better for the Publick that ten Innocent People ſhould ſuffer, than that one Guilty ſhould eſcape; and it becomes every good Perſon to ſacrifice their Conſcience to the Benefit of the Publick.

sp.speaker: Hil.
sp.p: Would you perſuade me to perjure my ſelf?

sp.speaker: Squeez.
sp.p: By no means. Not for the World. Perjury indeed! do you think I do not know what Perjury is, better than you? He did attempt to Raviſh you, you own; very well. He that attempts to do you an Injury, hath done it in his Heart. Beſides, a Woman may be Raviſhed, ay and many a Woman hath been Raviſhed, ay and Men been hanged for it—when ſhe hath not certainly known ſhe hath been Raviſhed.

sp.speaker: Hil.
sp.p: You are a great Caſuiſt in Conſcience. But you may ſpare your ſelf any further Trouble: for I aſſure you it will be in vain.

sp.speaker: Squeez.
sp.p:
I ſee where your Heſitation hangs, you are afraid of ſpoiling your Trade—You think Severity to a Cuſtomer, will keep People from your Houſe.—
Pray anſwer me one Queſtion—How long have you been upon the Town?

sp.speaker: Hil.
sp.p: What do you mean?

sp.speaker: Squeez.
sp.p: Come, come, I ſee you are but a Novice, and I like you the better: For yours is the only Buſineſs, wherein People do not profit by Experience—You are very handſome—It is Pity you ſhould continue in this abandoned State—Give me a Kiſs—Nay be not coy to me—I proteſt you are as full of Beauty as the Roſe is of Sweetneſs, and I of Love as its Stalk is full Briars—Oh! that we were as cloſely joined together too.

sp.speaker: Hil.
sp.p: Why you will commit a Rape your ſelf, Mr. Juſtice.

sp.speaker: Squeez.
sp.p: If I thought you would prove conſtant, I would take you into keeping: for I have not liked a Woman ſo much theſe many Years.

sp.speaker: Hil.
sp.p: I will humour this old Villain, I am reſolved.

sp.speaker: Squeez.
sp.p: What think you, could you be conſtant to a vigorous, healthy, middle-aged Man, hey!—could this buy thy Affections off from a ſet of idle Raſcals, who carry their Gold upon their Backs; and have Pockets as empty as their Heads? Fellows who are greater Curſes on a Woman than the Vapours; for as thoſe perſuade her into imaginary Diſeaſes, theſe preſent her with real.—Let thy Silence give Conſent; here take this Purſe as an Earneſt of what I'll do for you.

sp.speaker: Hil.
sp.p: Well, and what ſhall I do for this?

sp.speaker: Squeez.
sp.p: You ſhall do—You ſhall do nothing, I will do: I will be a Verb Active, and you ſhall be a Verb Paſſive.

sp.speaker: Hil.
sp.p: I wiſh you be not of the Neuter Gender.

sp.speaker: Squeez.
sp.p: Why you little arch Rogue, do you underſtand Latin, Huſſy?

sp.speaker: Hil.
sp.p: A little, Sir! my Father was a Country Parſon, and gave all his Children a good Education. He taught his Daughters to write and read himſelf.

sp.speaker: Squeez.
sp.p: What, have you Siſters then?

sp.speaker: Hil.
sp.p: Alack-a-day, Sir! ſixteen of us, and all in the ſame way of Buſineſs.

sp.speaker: Squeez.
sp.p: Ay, this it is to teach Daughters to write. I would as ſoon put a Sword into the Hand of a Madman, as a Pen into thoſe of a Woman; for a Pen in the Hand of a Woman is as ſure an Inſtrument of Propagation, as a Sword in that of a Madman is of Deſtruction [Aſide.] —Sure, my Dear, the Spirit of Love muſt run very ſtrongly in the Blood of your whole Family.

sp.speaker: Hil.
sp.p: Oh, Sir! it was a villanous Man of War that harboured near us—My poor Siſters were ruined by the Officers, and I fell a Martyr to the Chaplain.

sp.speaker: Squeez.
sp.p: Ay, ay, the Sailors are as fatal to our Women as the Soldiers are. One Venus roſe from the Sea, and thouſands have ſet in it—But not Venus her ſelf could compare to thee, my little Honey-ſuckle.

sp.speaker: Hil.
sp.p: Be not ſo hot, Sir.

sp.speaker: Squeez.
sp.p: Bid the Touchwood be cold behind the Burning-glaſs. The Touchwood is not more eaſily kindled by the Sun, than I by your dear Eyes.

sp.speaker: Hil.
sp.p: The Touch wood is not drier, I dare ſwear.

sp.speaker: Squeez.
sp.p: But hark, I hear my Wife returning—leave word with my Clerk where I ſhall ſend to you—I will be the kindeſt of Keepers, very conſtant, and very liberal.—

sp.speaker: Hil.
sp.p: Two charming Qualities in a Lover!

sp.speaker: Squeez.
sp.p: My pretty Noſe-gay, you will find me vaſtly preferable to idle young Rakehells. Beſides, you are ſafe with me. You are as ſafe with a Juſtice in England, as a Prieſt abroad; Gravity is the beſt Cloak for Sin, in all Countries—Be ſure to be punctual to the Time I ſhall appoint you.

sp.speaker: Hil.
sp.p: Be not afraid of me.

sp.speaker: Squeez.
sp.p: Adieu, my pretty Charmer. I ſhall burn with Impatience.

div.head: SCENE VI.
div.p:
Go thy ways for a charming Girl! Now if I can get her at this wild Fellow's Expence, I ſhall have performed the part of a ſhrewd Juſtice; for I would make others
pay for my Sins, as well as their own. I fancy my Wife hath ſufficiently frightned him by this, and that he will truckle to any Terms to be acquitted; for I muſt own ſhe will pump a Man much better than I—Oh! here they come; I muſt deal with my Gentleman now, in another Style.

sp.speaker: Ramb.
sp.p: Well, Sir, is the Lady determined to ſwear ſtoutly?

sp.speaker: Squeez.
sp.p: Truly, it is hard to ſay what ſhe determines; ſhe is gone to ask the Advice of a Divine and a Lawyer.

sp.speaker: Ramb.
sp.p: Then the odds is againſt me: for the Lawyer will certainly adviſe her to ſwear, and it is poſſible the Prieſt may not contradict her in it.

sp.speaker: Squeez.
sp.p: It is indeed a tickliſh Point, and it were adviſable to make it up as ſoon as poſſible. The firſt Loſs is always the leaſt. It is better to wet your Coat than your Skin, and to run home when the Clouds begin to drop, than in the middle of the Storm. In ſhort, it were better to give a brace of hundred Pounds to to make up the Matter now, than to venture the Conſequence. I am heartily concerned, to ſee a Gentleman in ſuch a Misfortune. I am ſorry the Age is ſo corrupt. Really I expect to ſee ſome grievous and heavy Judgment fall on the Nation. We are as bad as ever Sodom and Gomorrah were, and I wiſh we may not be as miſerable.

sp.speaker: Ramb.
sp.p: Heark'e, Juſtice; I take a Sermon to be the firſt Puniſhment which a Man undergoes after conviction. It is very hard I muſt be condemned to it before-hand.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Squeez.
sp.p: Nay, Sir, I am ſure Mr. Squeezum ſpeaks for your good.—I ſhall get a Necklace out of this Affair.

sp.speaker: Squeez.
sp.p: Ay, that I am ſure I do, my Intereſt ſways not one way or the other—I would, were I in that Gentleman's Circumſtances, do what I adviſe him to.

sp.speaker: Ramb.
sp.p: Faith, Sir, that I muſt doubt: for were you in my Circumſtances, you would not be worth the Money.

sp.speaker: Squeez.
sp.p: Nay, Sir, now you jeſt with me; a Gentleman can never be at a loſs for ſuch a Trifle.

sp.speaker: Ramb.
sp.p: Faith! you miſtake. I know a great many Gentlemen not worth three Farthings: he that reſolves to be honeſt cannot reſolve not to be poor.

sp.speaker: Squeez.
sp.p: A Gentleman, and poor! Sir, they are Contradictions. A Man may as well be a Scholar without Learning, as a Gentleman without Riches. But I have no time to dally with you. If you do not underſtand good Uſage, while it is dealt you, you may, when you feel the Reverſe. The Affair may now be made up for a Trifle; the time may come when your whole Fortune would be too little—An Hour's Delay in the making up an Offence is as dangerous as in the ſewing up of a Wound.

sp.speaker: Ramb.
sp.p: Well, you have over-perſuaded me, I'll take your Advice.

sp.speaker: Squeez.
sp.p: I'll engage you will not repent it—I don't queſtion but you will regard me as your Friend.

sp.speaker: Ramb.
sp.p: That I do indeed. And to give you the moſt ſubſtantial Inſtance of it, I will ask a Favour, which is expected only from the moſt intimate Friendſhip—which is, that you would be ſo kind to lend me the Money.

sp.speaker: Squeez.
sp.p: Alack-a-day, Sir, I have not ſuch a Sum in my Command. Beſides, how muſt it look in me, who am an Officer of Juſtice, to lend a Culprit Money wherewith to evade Juſtice! Alas, Sir, we muſt conſider our Characters in Life, we muſt act up to our Characters; and tho' I deviate a little from mine, in giving you Advice, it would be entirely forſaking the Character of a Juſtice to give you Money.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Squeez.
sp.p: I wonder how you could ask it.

sp.speaker: Ramb.
sp.p: Neceſſity obliges to any thing, Madam. Mr. Squeezum was ſo kind to ſhew me the Neceſſity of giving Money, and my Pockets were ſo cruel to ſhew me the Impoſſibility of it.

sp.speaker: Squeez.
sp.p: Well Sir, if you cannot pay for your Tranſgreſſions like the Rich, you muſt ſuffer for them like the Poor.—Here, Conſtable.

div.head: SCENE VIII.
div.stage: Squeezum, Mrs. Squeezum, Ramble, Staff, Conſtables.

sp.speaker: Squeez.
sp.p: Take away your Priſoner, keep him in ſafe Cuſtody till farther Orders. If you come to a wiſer Reſolution within theſe two Hours, ſend me Word; after that it will be too late.

sp.speaker: Ramb.
sp.p: Heark'e, Mr. Juſtice, you had better uſe me as you ought, and acquit me; for if you do any thing which you cannot defend, hang me if I am not revenged on you.

sp.speaker: Squeez.
sp.p: Hang you!—I wiſh there may not be more Meaning in thoſe Words than you imagine.

sp.speaker: Ramb.
sp.p: 'Sdeath! you old Raſcal, I can ſcarce forbear rattling thoſe old dry Bones of thine, till they crack thy withered Skin.

sp.speaker: Squeez.
sp.p: Bear Evidence of this, I am threatned in the Execution of my Office.

sp.speaker: Ramb.
sp.p: Come, honeſt Mr. Conſtable, Mr. nocturnal Juſtice, let me go any where from this Fellow—the Night hath choſen a better Juſtice than the Day.

sp.speaker: Squeez.
sp.p: I am afraid I ſhall make nothing of this Fellow at laſt. I have a Mind to diſcharge him.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Squeez.
sp.p: Oh! by no means; for I am ſure he hath Money.

sp.speaker: Squeez.
sp.p: Yes, and ſo am I. But ſuppoſe he will not part with it; it is impoſſible to take it from him; for there is no Law yet in being to skreen a Juſtice of Peace from a downright Robbery.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Squeez.
sp.p: Try him a little longer, however.

sp.speaker: Squeez.
sp.p:
I will, 'till the Afternoon; but if he ſhould not conſent by that Time, I muſt diſcharge him, for
I have no Hopes in the Woman's Swearing. She is diſcharged already.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Squeez.
sp.p: I'll make him a Viſit at the Conſtable's Houſe, and try if I can alarm him into a Compoſition. I may make him do more than you imagine.

sp.speaker: Squeez.
sp.p: Do ſo, my Dear;—I doubt not your Power—Good-morrow, Honey.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Squeez.
sp.p: But, my Dear, pray remember the Hundred Guineas.

sp.speaker: Squeez.
sp.p: Yes, yes, I ſhall remember them; they are not likely to be ſoon forgotten.—Follow me to my Eſcritore.

div.head: SCENE X.
div.p: Since you are ſure of going to the Devil, honeſt Spouſe, I'll take Care to equip you with a Pair of Horns, that you may be as like one another as poſſible. This dear wild Fellow muſt be mine, and ſhall be mine: I like him ſo well, that if he had even raviſhed me, on my Conſcience I ſhould have forgiven him.

sp.speaker: Wor.
sp.p: Upon my Word, Mr. Politick, I am heartily ſorry for this Occaſion of renewing our Acquaintance. I can imagine the Tenderneſs of a Parent, tho' I never was one.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.p: Indeed, Neighbour Worthy, you cannot imagine half the Troubles, without having undergone them. Matrimony balks our Expectations every way, and our Children as ſeldom prove Comforts to us as our Wives. I had but two—whereof one was hanged long ago—and the other I ſuppoſe may be in a fair Way by this.

sp.speaker: Wor.
sp.p: In what manner did ſhe eſcape from you?

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.p: She had taken Leave of me to retire to Reſt, not half an Hour before I heard of her Departure. I impute it all to the wicked Inſtructions of an Imp of the Devil called a Chamber-maid, who is the Companion of her Flight.

sp.speaker: Wor.
sp.p: But do you know of no Lover?

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.p: Let me ſee—hey!—There hath been a Fellow in a Red Coat, with whom ſhe hath converſed for ſome time, in ſpite of my Teeth.

sp.speaker: Wor.
sp.p: Depend on it, He is the Occaſion of your Loſs. I can grant you a Warrant againſt him, if you know his Name, tho' I fear you are too late.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.p: No, Sir, I am not too late; my Daughter is an Heireſs, and you know the Puniſhment for ſtealing an Heireſs. If I could hang the Raſcal, it would be ſome Satisfaction.

sp.speaker: Wor.
sp.p: That will be impoſſible, without her Conſent; and truly, if ſhe be married, I would adviſe you to follow the Example of that Emperor, who when he diſcovered ſomething worſe than a Marriage, between one of his Subjects and his Daughter, choſe rather to let him enjoy her as his own, than puniſh him.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.p: Pray where did that Emperor reign?

sp.speaker: Wor.
sp.p: I have almoſt forgotten, but I think it was one of the Greek Emperors, or one of the Turks.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.p: Bring me no Example from the Turks, good Mr. Worthy, I find no ſuch Affinity in our Intereſts. Sir, I dread and abhor the Turks. I wiſh we do not feel them, before we are aware.

sp.speaker: Wor.
sp.p: But Sir—

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.p: But me no buts—what can be the Reaſon of all this warlike Preparation, which all our Newspapers have informed us of. Yes, and the ſame Newspapers a hundred times in the ſame Words. Is the Deſign againſt Perſia? Is the Deſign againſt Germany? Is the Deſign againſt Italy—Suppoſe we ſhould ſee Turkiſh Gallies in the Channel? We may feel them, yes, we may feel them in the midſt of our Security; Troy was taken in its Sleep, and ſo may we.

sp.speaker: Wor.
sp.p: Sure, Sir, you are aſleep, or in a Dream—

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.p: Yes, yes, theſe things are called idle Dreams—the juſteſt Apprehenſions may be ſtyled Dreams—but let me tell you, Sir, Men betray their own Ignorance often, in attacking that of other Men.

sp.speaker: Wor.
sp.p: But what is all this to your Daughter?

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.p: Never tell me of my Daughter, my Country is dearer to me than a thouſand Daughters; ſhould the Turks come among us, what would become of our Daughters then? and our Sons, and our Wives, and our Eſtates, and our Houſes, and our Religion, and our Liberty.—When a Turkiſh Aga ſhould command our Nobility, and Janizaries make Grandfathers of Lords? Where ſhould we look for Britain then?

sp.speaker: Wor.
sp.p: Truly, where I may look for Mr. Politick now, in the Clouds.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.p: Give me leave, Sir, only to let you a little into the preſent State of Turkey.

sp.speaker: Wor.
sp.p: I muſt beg to be excuſed, Sir; if I can be of any Service to you, in relation to your Daughter, you may command my Attention: I may probably defend you from your own Countrymen, but truly from the Turks I cannot.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.p: I am glad to hear you have ſome Apprehenſion of them, as well as my ſelf.—That you are not ſo ſtupidly beſotted, as I meet with ſome People at the Coffee-houſe; but perhaps you are not enough apprized of the Danger. Give me leave only to ſhew you, how it is poſſible for the Grand Signior to find an Ingreſs into Europe.—Suppoſe, Sir, this Spot I ſtand on to be Turkey—then here is Hungary—Very well—here is France, and here is England—granted—then we will ſuppoſe he had Poſſeſſion of Hungary—what then remains but to conquer France, before we find him at our own Coaſt.—But, Sir, this is not all the Danger; now I will ſhew you how he can come by Sea to us.

sp.speaker: Wor.
sp.p: Dear Sir, refer that to ſome other time; you have ſufficiently ſatisfied me, I aſſure you.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.p: It is almoſt time to go to the Coffee-houſe—ſo dear Mr. Worthy, I am your moſt obedient Servant.

sp.speaker: Wor.
sp.p: Mr. Politick, your very humble Servant.

div.head: SCENE XII.
div.p: I recollect the Dawnings of this political Humour to have appeared when we were at the Bath together, but it hath riſen finely in theſe ten Years. What an Enthuſiaſm muſt it have arrived to, when it could make him forget the Loſs of his only Daughter! The greateſt Part of Mankind labour under one Delirium or other: And Don Quixotte differed from the reſt, not in Madneſs, but the Species of it. The Covetous, the Prodigal, the Superſtitious, the Libertine, and the Coffee-houſe Politician, are all Quixottes in their ſeveral Ways.
div.l: That Man alone from Madneſs free, we find,
Who, by no wild unruly Paſſion blind,
To Reaſon gives the Conduct of his Mind.

sp.speaker: Hil.
sp.p: DEAR Cloris.

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.p: Dear Madam, is it you? you altogether?

sp.speaker: Hil.
sp.p: Ay, ay, altogether, thank Heavens! I had like to have loſt ſomething, but all's ſafe I aſſure you.

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.p: Ah! Madam, I wiſh it were.

sp.speaker: Hil.
sp.p: What, don't you believe me?

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.p: I wiſh you could not me, or I my ſelf. Poor Capt. Conſtant—

sp.speaker: Hil.
sp.p: What of him?

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.p: Oh! Madam!

sp.speaker: Hil.
sp.p: Speak quickly, or kill me, which you pleaſe—

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.p: —Is taken up for a Rape.

sp.speaker: Hil.
sp.p: How!

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.p: It is too true, his own Servant told me.

sp.speaker: Hil.
sp.p: His Servant belied him, and ſo do you—ſhew me where he is, if he be in a Dungeon, I'll find him out.

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.p: Very generous indeed, Madam! A King ſhould ſooner viſit a Priſoner for Treaſon, than I a Lover for a Rape.

sp.speaker: Hil.
sp.p: It would be unpardonable in me to entertain ſo flagrant a Belief at the firſt hearing, againſt a Man who hath given me ſuch ſubſtantial Proofs of his Conſtancy: Beſides, an Affair of my own makes me the more doubtful of the Truth of this; but if there appear any Proof of ſuch a Fact I will drive him for ever from my Thoughts.

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.p: Yes, Madam, Juſtice Squeezum will take care to have him driven another Way.

sp.speaker: Hil.
sp.p: Juſtice Squeezum! let me hug you for that Information. Now, I can almoſt ſwear he is Innocent: I have ſuch an Adventure to ſurprize you with; but let me not loſe a Moment—come, ſhew me the way.

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.p: Poor Creature! She knows the way to her Deſtruction too well—but it would be Impertinence in a Servant to put her out of it.

div.head: SCENE II.
div.p:
I begin to be of that Philoſopher's Opinion, who ſaid, that whoever will entirely conſult his own Happineſs, muſt be little concerned about the Happineſs of others. Good-nature is Quixotiſm, and every Princeſs Micomicona will lead her Deliverer into a Cage. What had I to do to interpoſe! What harm did the Misfortunes of an unknown Woman bring me, that I ſhould
hazard my own Happineſs and Reputation on her Account?—But ſure, to ſwear a Rape againſt me for having reſcued her from a Raviſher, is an unparalelled Piece of Ingratitude.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Staff.
sp.p: Will your Honour pleaſe to drink a Dram, or ſome 'Rack Punch?

sp.speaker: Conſt.
sp.p: Dear Madam, do not trouble me; I can drink nothing.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Staff.
sp.p: Truly, Sir, but I can. Not trouble you! I had never ſuch a Cuſtomer here before. You a Captain charged with a Rape!—I ſhould ſooner take you for ſome poor Attorney, charged with Forgery and Perjury: o a travelling Parſon, with ſtealing a Gown and Caſſock.

sp.speaker: Conſt.
sp.p: Drink what you will, and I'll pay what you pleaſe.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Staff.
sp.p: Thank your Honour! Your Honour will not be offended, I hope—we ſtand at a great Rent: and truly, ſince this Gin Act, Trade hath been ſo dull, that I have often wiſhed my Husband would live by the Highway himſelf, inſtead of taking Highwaymen.

sp.speaker: Conſt
sp.p: You are not the only Wife who would give her Husband this Advice, I dare ſwear. Nay, were Men all ſo uxorious to take it, Tyburn would have as much Buſineſs as Doctors-Commons.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Staff.
sp.p: I wiſh it had more; for we muſt ſtand and fall by one another; no buſineſs there, no Buſineſs here; and truly Captain, 'tis with Sorrow I ſay it, where we have one Felon now, we had ten, a Year or two ago—I have not ſeen one Priſoner brought in for a Rape this Fortnight, except your Honour. I hope your Handſel will be lucky.

sp.speaker: Staff.
sp.p: Captain, your Servant, I ſuppoſe you will be glad of Company—here is a very civil Gentleman, I aſſure you.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Staff.
sp.p: More Gentlemen! This is rare News indeed.

sp.speaker: Conſt.
sp.p: I had rather be alone.

sp.speaker: Staff.
sp.p: I have but this one Priſon-Room, Captain: beſides, I aſſure you, this is no common Fellow, but a very fine Gentleman, a Captain too—and as merry a one—

sp.speaker: Conſt.
sp.p: What is the Cauſe of his Misfortune?

sp.speaker: Staff.
sp.p: A Rape, Captain, a Rape—no diſhonourable Offence—I would not have brought any Scoundrels into your Honour's Company: but Rape and Murder no Gentleman need be aſhamed of; and this is an honeſt Brother-Raviſher—I have raviſhed Women my ſelf formerly: but a Wife blunts a Man's Edge. When once you are married, you will leave off Raviſhing, I warrant you—to be bound in Wedlock is as good a Security againſt Rapes, as to be bound over to the Peace is againſt Murther.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Staff.
sp.p: My Husband will have his Jeſt. I hope your Honour will pardon him.

sp.speaker: Staff.
sp.p: But here is the Gentleman.

sp.speaker: Conſt.
sp.p: Prodigious!

sp.speaker: Ramb.
sp.p: Dear Conſtant!

sp.speaker: Conſt.
sp.p: What in the Name of Wonder hath brought you to England?

sp.speaker: Ramb.
sp.p: What in the Devil's Name hath brought thee to the Conſtable's?

sp.speaker: Conſt.
sp.p: Only a Rape, Sir, no diſhonourable Offence, as Mr. Conſtable hath it.

sp.speaker: Ramb.
sp.p: You jeſt.

sp.speaker: Staff.
sp.p: No, Sir, upon my Word the Captain is in earneſt.

sp.speaker: Ramb.
sp.p: Why I ſhould ſooner have ſuſpected Ermin or Lawn-Sleeves. But I ſee Gravity and Hypocriſy are inſeparable—Well, give me thy Hand, Brother, for our Fortunes agree exactly.

sp.speaker: Staff.
sp.p: And will agree in the End, I don't queſtion. This is not the firſt time of their meeting together on this Account; a Couple of old Whore-maſters, I warrant 'em.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Staff.
sp.p: Will your Honours pleaſe to drink any Punch, noble Captains, it will keep up your Spirits.

sp.speaker: Staff.
sp.p: Don't force the Gentlemen, Wife, to drink whether they will or no.—I wiſh you well off this Affair—in the mean time, whatever my Houſe affords is at your Service—and let me aſſure you, the more you drink the leſs you will lament your Misfortune.

sp.speaker: Ramb.
sp.p: Spoken like a true Philoſopher.

sp.speaker: Ramb.
sp.p: But, dear Billy, I hope thou haſt not really committed, hey?

sp.speaker: Conſt.
sp.p: What I heartily repent of, I aſſure you. I reſcued a Woman in the Street, for which ſhe was ſo kind to ſwear a Rape againſt me; but it gives me no Uneaſineſs equal to the Pleaſure I enjoy in ſeeing you.

sp.speaker: Ramb.
sp.p: Ever kind and good-natur'd!

sp.speaker: Conſt.
sp.p: Yet I wiſh our Meeting had been on another Occaſion, for the Freedom of your Life makes me ſuſpect the Conſequence of your Confinement may be heavier than mine.

sp.speaker: Ramb.
sp.p: I can't tell what the Conſequence may be, nor ſhall I trouble my ſelf about it: But I aſſure thee, no ſucking Babe can be more innocent. If our Caſes differ in any thing, it is in this, that my Woman hath not ſworn.

sp.speaker: Conſt.
sp.p:
This pleaſes me indeed!—But pray, how
came you to leave the Indies, where I thought you had been ſettled for Life?

sp.speaker: Ramb.
sp.p: Why on the ſame Account that I went thither, that I now am here, by which I live, and for which I live, a Woman.

sp.speaker: Conſt.
sp.p: A Woman!

sp.speaker: Ramb.
sp.p: Ay, a fine, young, rich Woman! a Widow with Fourſcore Thouſand Pounds in her Pocket—there's a North Star to ſteer by.

sp.speaker: Conſt.
sp.p: What is her Name?

sp.speaker: Ramb.
sp.p: Her Name!—her Name is Ramble.

sp.speaker: Conſt.
sp.p: What, Married!

sp.speaker: Ramb.
sp.p: Ay, Sir; ſoon after you left the Indies, honeſt Mr. Ingot left the World, and me the Heir to his Wife with all her Effects.

sp.speaker: Conſt.
sp.p: I wiſh you Joy, dear Jack; this thy good Fortune hath ſo filled me with Delight, that I have no Room for my own Sorrows.

sp.speaker: Ramb.
sp.p: But I have not unfolded half yet.

sp.speaker: Sot.
sp.p: [without.] Let two Quarts of Rum be made into Punch, let it be hot—hot as Hell.

sp.speaker: Ramb.
sp.p: D'ye hear, we are in a fine Condition 'faith!

sp.speaker: Sot.
sp.p: Here they are, here are a Brace of deſponding Whore-maſters for you—Ramble, what nothing to ſay in Praiſe of the Women, Mark Anthony made a fine Bargain, hey, when he gave the World for a Woman? 'Sdeath! if he had been alive now I'd have waged Six Gallons of Claret, I had ſeen him hanged for a Rape—as I ſhall very ſuddenly my two worthy Friends.

sp.speaker: Ramb.
sp.p: Hearkee, Sotmore, if you ſay any thing againſt the Women, we'll cut your Throat, and toſs Juſtice in a Murder into the Bargain.

sp.speaker: Sot.
sp.p:
Not ſpeak againſt Women! you ſhall as ſoon compel me not to drink; you ſhall ſow up my Lips,
if you do either—Here, you, let the Punch be gotten ready.

sp.speaker: Staff.
sp.p: It ſhall, an't pleaſe your Honour. (This Gentleman is a rare Cuſtomer to a Houſe, I wiſh he would commit a Rape too.)

sp.speaker: Conſt.
sp.p: You muſt not rail againſt the Ladies, Sotmore, before Ramble; for he is a married Man.

sp.speaker: Ramb.
sp.p: And what is better, my Wife is at the bottom of the Sea.

sp.speaker: Sot.
sp.p: And what is worſe, all her Effects are at the bottom of the Sea with her.

sp.speaker: Conſt.
sp.p: How!

sp.speaker: Ramb.
sp.p: Faith! Sotmore hath ſpoken Truth for once.—Notwithſtanding my Pleaſantry, the Lady and her Fortune are both gone together; ſhe went to the other World Fourſcore Thouſand ſtrong; and if there be any ſuch thing there, I don't queſtion but ſhe is married again by this Time.

sp.speaker: Sot.
sp.p: You would not take my Advice. I have cautioned thee never to truſt any thing on the ſame Bottom with a Woman. I would not enſure a Ship that had a Woman on Board, for double the Price.—The Sins of one Woman are enough to draw down a Judgment on a Fleet.

sp.speaker: Ramb.
sp.p: Here's a Fellow, who, like a Prude, makes Sin a Handle to his Abuſe.—Art thou not aſhamed to mention Sin—who art a Cargo of Iniquity? why wilt thou fill thy venom'd Mouth with that of others, when thou haſt ſuch Stores of thy own?

sp.speaker: Conſt.
sp.p: What occaſioned your ſeparating?

sp.speaker: Ramb.
sp.p: A Storm, and my ill Stars. I left the Ship wherein ſhe was to dine with the Captain of one of our Convoy, when a ſudden violent Storm ariſing, I loſt ſight of her Ship, and from that Day have never ſeen or heard of her.

sp.speaker: Sot.
sp.p:
Nor ever will—I heartily hope. Tho' as for the Innocent Cheſts, thoſe I wiſh deliver'd out of the
Deep. But the Sea knows its own good: It will be ſure to keep the Money, tho' poſſibly it may refund the Woman; for a Woman will ſwim like a Cork, and they are both of the ſame Value, nay the latter is the more valuable, as it preſerves our Wine, which Women often ſpoil.

sp.speaker: Conſt.
sp.p: Why, Sotmore, Wine is the Touchſtone of all Merit with thee, as Gold is to a Stock-jobber, and thou would'ſt as ſoon ſell thy Soul for a Bottle, as he for a Guinea.

sp.speaker: Sot.
sp.p: Wine, Sir, is as apt a Compariſon to every thing that is good, as Woman is to every thing that is bad.

sp.speaker: Conſt.
sp.p: Fie, Sotmore! this railing againſt the Ladies will make your Company as ſcandalous to Gentlemen, as railing at Religion would to a Parſon.

sp.speaker: Ramb.
sp.p: Right, Conſtant! they are my Religion, I am the High-Prieſt of the Sex.

sp.speaker: Sot.
sp.p: Women and Religion! Women and the Devil: he leaves his Votaries in the Lurch, and ſo do they.

sp.speaker: Conſt.
sp.p: I fancy, Ramble, this Friend of ours will turn Parſon, one day or other—

sp.speaker: Ramb.
sp.p: If he was not ſuch a Sot, I ſhould think it poſſible:

sp.speaker: Sot.
sp.p: Why faith! I am almoſt ſuperſtitious enough to fancy this a Judgment on thee for breaking thy Word.—Did I not tell thee, thou wert ſtroling off to ſome little dirty Whore? and you ſee the Truth of my Prophecy.

sp.speaker: Ramb.
sp.p: Thou art in the right: It was not only a Whore, but the moſt Impudent of all Whores—a modeſt Whore.

sp.speaker: Conſt.
sp.p: A modeſt Whore! let her be married to an honeſt Attorney, by all means.

sp.speaker: Ramb.
sp.p: And ſent together to People His Majeſty's Plantations.

sp.speaker: Sot.
sp.p: Modeſty now-a-days as often covers Impudence, as it doth Uglineſs. It is as uncertain a ſign of Virtue as Quality is, or as fine Cloaths are of Quality.

sp.speaker: Ramb.
sp.p: Yet to do her Right: the Perſuaſions of the Juſtice could not prevail with her to perjure herſelf.

sp.speaker: Sot.
sp.p: Conſcientious Strumpet! She hopes to pick your Pocket another time, which it were Charity to thee to wiſh ſhe might: for if thou eſcapeſt this, ſhe certainly will have an Opportunity.

sp.speaker: Ramb.
sp.p: Pray, honeſt Nol, how didſt thou find us out? for a Boy would as ſoon have ſent for his Schoolmaſter when he was caught in an Orchard, as I for thee on this Occaſion.

sp.speaker: Sot.
sp.p: Find you out! why the Town rings of you—there is not a Husband or Guardian in it, but what is ready to get drunk for Joy. If the Woman be not Gold-Proof, ſhe will be bribed to ſwear againſt you. You are a Nuſance, Sir! I don't believe he hath been in Town Six Days, and he hath had above ſixteen Women.

sp.speaker: Ramb.
sp.p: And they are a nobler Pleaſure than ſo many Gallons which thou haſt ſwallowed in that time.

sp.speaker: Sot.
sp.p: Sir, I pay my Vintner, and therefore do no Injury.

sp.speaker: Ramb.
sp.p: And, Sir, I do no Injury: and therefore have no Reaſon to pay.

sp.speaker: Sot.
sp.p: Hey-day! is taking away a Man's Wife or Daughter no Injury?

sp.speaker: Ramb.
sp.p: Not when the Wife is weary of her Husband, and the Daughter longs for one.

sp.speaker: Conſtant.
sp.p: Art thou not aſhamed, Sotmore, to throw a Man's Sins in his Face, while he is ſuffering for them?

sp.speaker: Sotm.
sp.p: That is the time, Sir; beſides you ſee what an effect it hath on him: you might as well rail at a Knight of the Poſt in the Pillory.

sp.speaker: Ramb.
sp.p: Let him alone, the Punch will be here immediately, and then he'll have no Leiſure to rail.

sp.speaker: Sot.
sp.p:
Is it not enough to make a Man rail, to have parted with a Friend happy in the Night, and to find him the next Morning in ſo fair a Way to—Death and Damnation! Shew me the Whore, I'll be revenged on her and the whole Sex. If thou art
hanged for Raviſhing her, I'll be hanged for Murdering her. Deſcribe the little Miſchief to me. Is ſhe tall, ſhort, black, brown, fair? In what Form hath the Devil diſguiſed himſelf?

sp.speaker: Ramb.
sp.p: In a very Beautiful one, I aſſure you: ſhe hath the fineſt Shape that ever was beheld, genteel to a Miracle, then the brighteſt Eyes that ever glanced on a Lover, the prettieſt little Mouth, and Lips as red as a Cherry: And for her Breaſts, not Snow, Marble, Lillies, Alabaſter, Ivory can come up to their Whiteneſs; but their little, pretty, firm, round Form, no Art can imitate, no Thought conceive—Oh! Sotmore, I could die ten thouſand Millions of Times upon them.—

sp.speaker: Sot.
sp.p: You are only like to die once for them.

sp.speaker: Conſt.
sp.p: All theſe Raptures about a common Whore, Ramble?

sp.speaker: Sot.
sp.p: Ay, every Woman he ſees, they are all alike to him, modeſt, or immodeſt, high or low, from the Garret to the Cellar, St. James's to the Stews; find him but a Woman, and he'll make an Angel of her.—He hath the ſame Taſte for Women, as a Child for Pictures, or a hungry Glutton for an Entertainment: every Piece is a Venus, and every Diſh an Ortelan.

sp.speaker: Ramb.
sp.p: To ſay the Truth of her, Sotmore muſt have allowed her handſome, and I muſt allow her to have been a damn'd, confounded, common—

sp.speaker: Ramb.
sp.p: Ha! Conjured up, by Jupiter! Well, my little Enemy, do the Prieſt and the Lawyer conſent—and will you ſwear—ha!

sp.speaker: Hil.
sp.p: [Not regarding Ramble, runs to Conſtant.] My Conſtant!

sp.speaker: Ramb.
sp.p: Hey-day! what, are we both in for Raviſhing the ſame Woman?—I ſee by her Fondneſs, he hath really Raviſhed her.

sp.speaker: Conſt.
sp.p: O, Hilaret! this Kindneſs of yours ſinks me the deeper; can you bear to think on one accuſed of ſuch a Crime as I am?

sp.speaker: Hil.
sp.p: Never to believe it can I bear.

sp.speaker: Conſt.
sp.p: How ſhall I repay this Goodneſs! Then by Heavens I am innocent.

sp.speaker: Ramb.
sp.p: Hey! the Devil!—Is this Conſtant's Miſtreſs? Here will be fine Work, i'faith!

sp.speaker: Sotm.
sp.p: Is this the Lady that did you the Favour, Sir?

sp.speaker: Ramb.
sp.p: This the Lady! No—why this is a Woman of Virtue; tho' ſhe hath a great Reſemblance of the other, I muſt confeſs.

sp.speaker: Sotm.
sp.p: Then I ſuppoſe this is ſhe whom Conſtant hath Toaſted this half Year—his Honourable Miſtreſs, with a Pox.—Rare Company for a Man who is in Priſon for a Rape!

sp.speaker: Hil.
sp.p: And was you in that Scuffle which parted me and my Maid in Leiceſter-Fields?

sp.speaker: Conſt.
sp.p: It was there this unfortunate Accident happened, while I was going to the Place of our Appointment.

sp.speaker: Hil.
sp.p: It had like to have occaſioned another to me, which, that I eſcaped, I am to thank this Gentleman.

sp.speaker: Ram.
sp.p: Oh, Madam! your moſt obedient, humble Servant. Was it you, dear Madam?

sp.speaker: Conſt.
sp.p: Ha! is it poſſible my Friend can have ſo far indebted me!—This is a Favour I can never return.

sp.speaker: Ramb.
sp.p: You over-rate it, upon my Soul you do; I am ſufficiently repayed by this Embrace.

sp.speaker: Conſt.
sp.p: I can never repay thee.—Would'ſt thou have given me Worlds, it could not have equall'd the leaſt Favour conferr'd on this Lady.

sp.speaker: Ramb.
sp.p: I ſhould have conferred ſome Favours on her indeed, if ſhe would have accepted them.

sp.speaker: Hil.
sp.p: I am glad it is to Mr. Conſtant's Friend I am obliged.

sp.speaker: Sotm.
sp.p: Yes, you are damnably obliged to him for his Character of you.

sp.speaker: Conſt.
sp.p: My dear Hilaret, ſhall I beg to hear it all? I can have no Pleaſure equal to finding new Obligations to this Gentleman.

sp.speaker: Hil.
sp.p: Since you deſire it—

sp.speaker: Ramb.
sp.p: I fancy, Madam, your Fright at that time may have occaſioned your forgetting ſome Circumſtance; therefore ſince Capt. Conſtant deſires it, I will tell him the Story.—I had juſt parted from this Gentleman, when I heard a young Lady's Voice crying out for help; (I think the Word Rape was mentioned, but that I cannot perfectly remember;) upon this, making directly to the Place whence the Noiſe proceeded, I found this Lady in the Arms of a very rude Fellow—

sp.speaker: Hil.
sp.p: The moſt impudent Fellow, ſure, that ever was born!

sp.speaker: Ramb.
sp.p: A very impudent Fellow, and yet a very cowardly one; for the Moment I came up, he quitted his Hold, and was gone out of Sight in the Twinkling of an Eye.

sp.speaker: Conſt.
sp.p: My dear Ramble, what haſt thou done for me!

sp.speaker: Ramb.
sp.p: No Obligation, dear Conſtant! I would have done the ſame for any Man breathing. But to proceed; the Watch came up, who would not be ſatisfied with what ſhe then ſaid, but convey'd us both to the Round-Houſe, whence we were carried in the Morning before Juſtice Squeezum, and by him, notwithſtanding this Lady's Proteſtations, your humble Servant was committed to that Place where he now finds himſelf with this good Company.

sp.speaker: Conſt.
sp.p: Oh, my Friend!—May Heaven ſend me an Opportunity of ſerving thee in the ſame Manner!

sp.speaker: Ramb.
sp.p: May that be the only Prayer which it denies to Conſtant.

sp.speaker: Staff.
sp.p: The Punch is ready, Gentlemen, you may walk down; the Liberty of my Houſe is at your Service.

sp.speaker: Sotm.
sp.p: And that is Liberty enough, while thou haſt Punch here. If thy Houſe were a Sea of Punch, I would not prefer any Houſe in Town to it.

sp.speaker: Staff.
sp.p: Your Honour ſhall not want that.

sp.speaker: Sotm.
sp.p: And I ſhall want nothing more.

sp.speaker: Staff.
sp.p: Captain, a Word with you. [To Ramble.] There's Madam Squeezum below deſires to ſpeak with you alone.

sp.speaker: Ramb.
sp.p: Bring her up.—Sotmore, you muſt excuſe me a few Moments, Conſtant and this Lady will entertain you.

sp.speaker: Sotm.
sp.p: Let the Moments be very few. I'll lay Five Gallons to One, this Fellow hath another Whore in his Eye.

sp.speaker: Ramb.
sp.p: So; my Affair with my Friend's Miſtreſs is happily over.—That I ſhould not know a modeſt Woman! But there is ſo great an Affectation of Modeſty in ſome Women of the Town, and ſo great an Affectation of Impudence in ſome Women of Faſhion, that it is not impoſſible to miſtake. Now for Mrs. Juſtice, her Buſineſs with me is not exceeding difficult to gueſs.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Squeez.
