sp.p: You will think I have a vaſt deal of Charity, Captain, who am not only the Solicitreſs of your Liberty at home to my Husband, but can carry my Good-nature ſo far as to viſit you in your Confinement. I cannot ſay but I have a generous Pity for any one whom I imagine to be accuſed wrongfully.

sp.speaker: Ramb.
sp.p: I am obliged to you indeed, Madam, for that Suppoſal.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Squeez.
sp.p: You are for the Cauſe of it. Wherefore do you imagine I ventured my ſelf alone with you this Morning?

sp.speaker: Ramb.
sp.p: From your great Humanity, Madam.

sp.speaker: Mr. Squeez.
sp.p: Alas, Sir! it was to try whether you were really the Man you were reported to be; and I am certain I found you as inoffenſive, quiet, civil, well-bred a Gentleman as any virtuous Woman could have wiſhed. Your Behaviour was ſo modeſt, that I can never imagine it poſſible you ſhould have been guilty of a Rape. No over-grown Alderman of Sixty, or taper Beau of Six and Twenty, could have been more innocent Company.

sp.speaker: Ramb.
sp.p: Whu!—

sp.speaker: Mrs. Squeez.
sp.p: Your then Carriage hath wrought ſo great an Effect upon me, that I have ventured to truſt my ſelf here with you; nay, I could truſt my ſelf any where with ſo modeſt a Gentleman.

sp.speaker: Ramb.
sp.p: I'll take care, Madam, never to forfeit your good Opinion of me; you may truſt your ſelf with me any where; I'll never behave in any other manner than becomes the beſt-bred Man alive with the beſt-bred Lady. I ſwear by this ſoft Hand, theſe Lips, and all the Millions of Charms that dwell in this dear Body.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Squeez.
sp.p: What do you mean?

sp.speaker: Ramb.
sp.p: I know not what I mean; Tongue can't expreſs, nor Thought conceive—we can only feel the exquiſite Pleaſures Love has in ſtore.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Squeez.
sp.p: Nay, I proteſt, and vow.

sp.speaker: Ramb.
sp.p: Proteſtations are as vain as Struggling. This Cloſet hath a Bed in it that would not diſgrace a Palace.

sp.speaker: Sotm.
sp.p: [At the Door.] Why, Ramble! Jack Ramble! Art thou not aſhamed to leave thy Friends thus, for ſome little dirty Strumpet? If thou doſt not come immediately, we'll break open the Door, and drown her in Punch.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Squeez.
sp.p: [Softly.] I am undone!—

sp.speaker: Ramb.
sp.p: Fear nothing—Go to your Bowl, I'll come this Inſtant.

sp.speaker: Sotm.
sp.p: I'll not wag without you.

sp.speaker: Ramb.
sp.p: Then I'll come down, break your Bowl and ſpill all your Liquor.

sp.speaker: Sot.
sp.p: Bring thy Whore along with thee; there's one there already, ſhe'll be glad of her Company: If you don't come in an Inſtant I will be back again.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Squeez.
sp.p: What ſhall I do?

sp.speaker: Ramb.
sp.p: My Angel! Love ſhall inſtruct thee.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Squeez.
sp.p: Let me go—ſome other time—I will not run any Venture here.

sp.speaker: Ramb.
sp.p: I will not part with you.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Squeez.
sp.p: You ſhall hear from me in half an Hour. You ſhall have your Liberty, and I'll appoint you where to meet me.

sp.speaker: Ramb.
sp.p: Shall I depend on you?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Squeez.
sp.p: You may.—Adieu.—Don't follow me: I can ſlip out a back Way.

sp.speaker: Ramb.
sp.p: Farewel, my Angel!

div.head: SCENE XII.
div.p:
Confound this drunken Raſcal! This is not the firſt Time he hath ſpoiled an Intrigue for me. But hold, as I am to have my Liberty before-hand, I don't think this half Hour's Delay at all unlucky. That Conſideration may ſufficiently compenſate the ſtaying of my Stomach. This Adventure of mine begins to put on a tolerable Aſpect. An Intrigue with a rich Juſtice's Wife, is not to be ſlighted by a young Fellow of a deſperate Fortune. I do not doubt but in a very ſhort Time, when I am taken up for the next Rape, to bribe the Juſtice with his own Money.—Lend a Man your Gold, he may forget the Debt; venture your Life for him, he may forget the Obligation; but once engage his Wife, and you ſecure his Friendſhip. There is no Friend in all Extremity ſo ſure as your
Cuckold—and the ſureſt Hold you can take of a Man, as of a Bull, is by his Horns.

sp.speaker: Sotm.
sp.p: Ha! what's become of thy Wench? if thou hadſt none, thy Abſence was the more inexcuſable.

sp.speaker: Conſt.
sp.p: O Ramble! this our better Genius hath invented the moſt notable Plot!—Such a Net is laid for the Juſtice! it will at once entangle him and diſentangle us. Mr. Hoggſhead here is to play his Part too.

sp.speaker: Ramb.
sp.p: I am ſorry we cannot do without him; for ſhould there be any Claret in his way, he'd diſappoint the whole Affair for one Bottle.

sp.speaker: Sotm.
sp.p: Not for the beſt Burgundy in France. This Lady hath won my Heart by one Bumper.—By all the Pleaſures of Drinking, Madam, I like you more than your whole Sex put together. There is no Honeſty in Man or Woman, that will not drink. Honeſty is tried in Wine, as Gold is in the Fire. Madam, you have made a Conqueſt of me. I'll drink your Health as long as I can ſtand, and that's as long as a reaſonable Woman can require.

sp.speaker: Hil.
sp.p: I am exceedingly proud of my Conqueſt over a Man of Mr. Sotmore's good Senſe.

sp.speaker: Conſt.
sp.p: Upon my Word you may, you are the firſt Woman I believe he ever was civil to.

sp.speaker: Sotm.
sp.p: It was becauſe they none of them had your Merit; a Parcel of Tea-drinking Sluts.—If I had a Daughter that drank Tea, I would turn her out of Doors. The Reaſon that Men are honeſter than Women is, their Liquors are ſtronger. If the Sex were bred up to Brandy and Tobacco, if they all liked Drinking as well as you ſeem to do, Madam, I ſhould turn a Lover.

sp.speaker: Ramb.
sp.p: Why, Conſtant, ſuch another Compliment would make thee jealous.

sp.speaker: Hil.
sp.p: Upon my Word, he hath Reaſon already!

sp.speaker: Sotm.
sp.p: Madam, I like you; and if a Bottle of Burgundy were on one ſide, and you on the other, I do not know which I ſhould chuſe.

sp.speaker: Conſt.
sp.p: Thou would'ſt chuſe the Bottle, I am ſure.

sp.speaker: Ramb.
sp.p: But I long to hear this Conſpiracy.

sp.speaker: Sotm.
sp.p: Then it muſt be below. I ſtrictly forbid any Secrets to be told but at the Council-Table. The Roſe is ever underſtood over the Drinking-Room, and a Glaſs is the ſureſt Turnkey to the Lips.

sp.speaker: Conſt.
sp.p: That's contrary to the Opinion of Philoſophers.

sp.speaker: Sotm.
sp.p:
Of the ſober ones it may; but all your wiſe Philoſophers were a Set of the moſt drunken Dogs alive. I never knew a ſober Fellow but was an Aſs—and your Aſs is the ſobereſt of all Animals. Your ſober Philoſophers, and their Works, have been buried long ago. I remember a Saying of that great Philoſopher and Poet, Horace, who wrote in Falernian inſtead of Ink:
No Verſes laſt—can long eſcape the Night,
Which the dull ſcribling Water-drinkers write.

sp.speaker: Squeez.
sp.p: YOU delivered my Letter?

sp.speaker: Quill.
sp.p: Yes, an't pleaſe your Worſhip, I left it at the Coffee-Houſe, where ſhe directed me.

sp.speaker: Squeez.
sp.p: Very well.—Quill!

sp.speaker: Quill.
sp.p: Sir.

sp.speaker: Squeez.
sp.p:
I think I may truſt thee with any Secret—and what I am now going to tell, will ſhew thee what
a Confidence I put in thee.—In ſhort, Quill, I ſuſpect my Wife—

sp.speaker: Quill.
sp.p: Of what, Sir?

sp.speaker: Squeez.
sp.p: I am afraid that I am not the only Perſon free with her, and that I am free of the Corporation of Cuckolds.

sp.speaker: Quill.
sp.p: Then your Worſhip is free of all the Corporations in England.

sp.speaker: Squeez.
sp.p: Now thou knoweſt that there are very wholeſome Laws againſt Cuckoldom; the Advantage of a Man's Horns is, that he may ſhove his Wife out of Doors with them.

sp.speaker: Quill.
sp.p: And that is no inconſiderable Advantage.

sp.speaker: Squeez.
sp.p: But there muſt be a Diſcovery firſt. It is not enough that a Man knows himſelf to be a Cuckold, the World muſt know it too. He that will keep his Horns in his Pocket, muſt keep his Wife in his Boſom. Therefore, Quill, as it is in your Power to obſerve my Wife, I aſſure you a very handſome Reward on her Conviction; for I begin to find, that if I do not diſcover her, ſhe will ſhortly diſcover me, or ruin me by bribing her to hold her Tongue. It is not a little Gold will make a Gag for a Woman.

sp.speaker: Quill.
sp.p: Sir, I ſhall be as diligent as poſſible.

sp.speaker: Squeez.
sp.p: And I as liberal on your Succeſs.

div.head: SCENE II.
div.p: Indeed, Juſtice, that Bait will not do. I know you too well to truſt to your Liberality. Your Wife will reward Services better than you. Beſides, I have too much Honour to take Fees on both Sides.—And ſince I am her Pimp in ordinary, I'll go like an honeſt and dutiful Servant, and diſcover this Conſpiracy; for ſhould ſhe once be turn'd out of the Family, I ſhould make but a ſlender Market of this cloſefinger'd Juſtice, whoſe Covetouſneſs would ſuffer no Rogues to live but himſelf.

sp.speaker: Ramb.
sp.p: This little Miſtreſs of yours is the moſt dextrous Politician, if that drunken Puppy doth not diſappoint us.

sp.speaker: Conſt.
sp.p: Never fear him! he hath Cunning enough, and there hath been ſo long a War in his Head between Wine and his Senſes, that they ſeem now to have come to an Agreement that he is never to be quite in them, nor ever quite out of them; his Life is one continued Scene of being half Drunk.

sp.speaker: Ramb.
sp.p: Well, as we can be of no farther Uſe in the Affair, but muſt ſtay here and expect the Iſſue; pr'ythee tell me what hath become of you theſe three long long Years ſince you quitted the Service of the Eaſt-India Company, and came over to England with Sotmore?

sp.speaker: Conſt.
sp.p: Why, at my firſt Return to England, the Proſpect of War was in every one's Eye, and not only the Reports of the People, but the Augmentation of the Troops aſſured us of its Approach; upon which, I reſolved to embarque my ſmall Remains of Fortune in the Service of my Country, and obtained the ſame Commiſſion on that Occaſion, which I had enjoyed in the Indies. My Hiſtory is not very full of Adventures; I continued therein 'till the Reduction, when I ſhared the Fate of ſeveral unhappy brave Fellows, and was ſent a begging with a red Coat on my Back.

sp.speaker: Ramb.
sp.p: It is the Faculty of the Cloth to be ragged.—Red is as apt to be ragged, as White to be ſoil'd. It is commonly the Fate of our brave Soldiers to bring home ragged Cloaths, as well as Colours, and both are rewarded by Weſtminſter-Hall—the one is hung up in it, and the other is locked up ſafe by an Order from it; for, Heaven be prais'd! the Goals are always open Hoſpitals for us.

sp.speaker: Conſt.
sp.p: The only Happineſs which hath attended me ſince my Return, is my having contracted an Intimacy with that young Lady whom you ſaw here; which hath proceeded ſo far, that laſt Night we had appointed to meet in order to our Marriage; but as I was juſt arrived at the Place, a Woman well-dreſs'd was attacked in the Street by a Ruſſian; I immediately flying to her Aſſiſtance, the Fellow quitted her, and left me alone in the Poſſeſſion of the Watch, who early this Morning carried me before Juſtice Squeezum, and by him I was committed hither.

sp.speaker: Ramb.
sp.p: What, did ſhe appear againſt you?

sp.speaker: Conſt.
sp.p: No; they ſaid ſhe was ill of ſome Bruiſes ſhe had received, but deſired I might be kept in Cuſtody 'till the Afternoon, at which Time ſhe would appear againſt me. But by what Hilaret hath told us, and by ſome Methods which have been uſed to extort Money from me, I am inclined to fancy it all a contrived Piece of Villany of the Juſtice, and not of the Woman's, as I at firſt imagined.

sp.speaker: Ramb.
sp.p: Be aſſured of it;—if there be Roguery, the Juſtice hath the chief Part in it. But, comfort your ſelf with the Expectation of Revenge, for I think he cannot poſſibly eſcape the Net we have ſpread, unleſs the Devil have more Gratitude than he is reported to have, and will aſſiſt his very good Friend at a Criſis.

sp.speaker: Conſt.
sp.p: But, what do you intend in England, where you have no Friends?

sp.speaker: Ramb.
sp.p: I know not yet whether I have or no. I left an old Father here, and a rich one. He thought fit to turn me out of Doors for ſome Frolicks, which it is probable, if he yet lives, he may have forgiven me by this. But what's become of him I know not, for I have not heard one Word of him theſe Ten Years.

sp.speaker: Conſt.
sp.p: I think you have been vaſtly careleſs, in neglecting him ſo long.

sp.speaker: Ramb.
sp.p:
'Tis as I have acted in all Affairs of Life; my Thoughts have ever ſucceeded my Actions; the
Conſequence hath cauſed me to reflect when it was too late. I never reaſoned on what I ſhould do, but what I had done; as if my Reaſon had her Eyes behind, and could only ſee backwards.

sp.speaker: Staff.
sp.p: Here is a Letter for your Honour.

sp.speaker: Ramb.
sp.p: [Reads it.] Ay, this is a Letter indeed!

sp.speaker: Conſt.
sp.p: What is it?

sp.speaker: Ramb.
sp.p: My Freedom, under a Sign manual from the Queen of theſe Regions.

sp.speaker: Conſt.
sp.p: Explain.

sp.speaker: Ramb.
sp.p:
Then, Sir, in plain Engliſh, without either Trope or Figure, it is a Letter from the Juſtice's Wife, with an Order to the Conſtable for my Liberty. [Reads.]
SIR,
I Was no ſooner recovered of the Fright which that unmannerly Friend of yours occaſioned, than I have performed my Promiſe; you will find me at Home; the Conſtable hath Orders by the Bearer to acquit you.
Here's Good-nature for you! [Kiſſes the Letter.] Thou dear Wife of a damn'd Rogue of a Juſtice, I fly to thy Arms.

sp.speaker: Conſt.
sp.p: Heark'e! ſuppoſe you brought her to be a Witneſs to our Deſign—and—here, take this Letter of Aſſignation from the Juſtice to Hilaret; it will give your Diſcovery Credit.

sp.speaker: Ramb.
sp.p: An admirable Thought! I fly to execute it. Dear Conſtant, good-morrow. I hope when next we meet, we ſhall meet
sp.l: In happier Climes, and on a ſafer Shore,
Where no vile Juſtice ſhall invade us more.

sp.speaker: Conſt.
sp.p: Succeſs attend you.

sp.speaker: Squeez.
sp.p: No Woman been to enquire for Mr. Jones?

sp.speaker: Draw.
sp.p: Sir, I know of none, but I'll ask at the Bar if you pleaſe.

sp.speaker: Squeez.
sp.p: Do—and leave Word if any ſuch comes, to ſhew her up hither.—I have no Reaſon to doubt her Company, but I am impatient for it. I proteſt this Woman hath revived the Vigour of Youth in me; ſure, I muſt have over-reckoned my Years!—I cannot be above Forty-Nine at the moſt.—I wiſh this dear Girl was come.—I am afraid I did wrong in giving her thoſe Five Shillings, in a Purſe worth above Two Shillings more, which who knows but ſhe may be ſpending on ſome Bully, who will perhaps ſend another Preſent to me in return?

sp.speaker: Squeez.
sp.p: Oh! are you come—you little, pretty, dear, ſweet Rogue!—I have been waiting for you theſe—theſe four Hours at leaſt.

sp.speaker: Hil.
sp.p: Young Lovers are commonly earlier than their Appointment.

sp.speaker: Squeez.
sp.p: Give me a Kiſs for that.—Thou ſhalt find me a young Lover, a vigorous young Lover too.—Hit me a Slap in the Face, do.—Bow-wow! Bow-wow! I'll eat up your Cloaths.—Come, what will you drink? White or Red?—Women love White beſt.—Boy, bring half a Pint of Mountain.—Come, ſit down; do, ſit down.—Come, now let us hear the Story how you were firſt debauched.—Come—that I may put it down in my Hiſtory at Home. I have the Hiſtory of all the Women's Ruin that ever I lay with, and I call it, The Hiſtory of my own Times.

sp.speaker: Hil.
sp.p: I'll warrant it is as big as a Church-Bible.

sp.speaker: Squeez.
sp.p: It is really of a good reputable Size: I have done Execution in my Time.

sp.speaker: Hil.
sp.p: And may do Execution ſtill.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: [Without.] Half a Pint of Mountain in the Lion, ſcore.

sp.speaker: Squeez.
sp.p: Well—But now let me have the Hiſtory—Where did your Amour begin—at Church, I warrant you: more Amours begin at Church than end there.—Or perhaps, you went to ſee the Man of War—Going to ſee Sights hath ruined many a Woman. No wonder Children are Lovers of them, ſince ſo many owe their Being to them.

sp.speaker: Hil.
sp.p: [Aſide.] I thank you for that remembrance, I had forgot my Lover.—Ay, Sir, it was there indeed I ſaw him firſt, that was the fatal Scene of our Interview.

sp.speaker: Squeez.
sp.p: Well, and was the Amour managed by Letter, or by word of Mouth?

sp.speaker: Hil.
sp.p: By Letter, Sir. I believe he writ two Quires of Paper to me before I would ſend him an Anſwer, I returned him ſeveral un-opened, and then ſeveral others opened—But at laſt—he obtained an Anſwer.

sp.speaker: Squeez.
sp.p: Well, and after your Anſwer, what followed then?

sp.speaker: Hil.
sp.p: Oh! he thought himſelf ſure of me, as ſoon as I had anſwered his Letter.

sp.speaker: Squeez.
sp.p: Ay, I have always obſerved in my Amours, that when I received an Anſwer, I never failed of the Woman; a Woman follows her Letter infallibly: well, and what did he ſay in the ſecond Letter?

sp.speaker: Hil.
sp.p: Oh! he ſwore a thouſand fond things, that his Love ſhould laſt as long as his Life. That his whole Happineſs depended on me—and a vaſt deal of that Nature.

sp.speaker: Squeez.
sp.p: Ay, ay, juſt as I have done my ſelf. I find Whoring is as Methodical as the Law.

sp.speaker: Hil.
sp.p: And I fancy as tedious with you, old Gentle man.

sp.speaker: Squeez.
sp.p: Well, and how many Letters did you write to him, ey!—before—?

sp.speaker: Hil.
sp.p: Not many. He did not want much Encouragement.

sp.speaker: Squeez.
sp.p: Then paſſing over the reſt of the Suit, let us come to the laſt fatal Meeting.

sp.speaker: Hil.
sp.p: It was of a Sunday Morning.—

sp.speaker: Squeez.
sp.p: Right. My old method: When other People are gone to Church.

sp.speaker: Hil.
sp.p: In an exceeding hot Day.—

sp.speaker: Squeez.
sp.p: May or June?—Women and Cherries are commonly gathered in the ſame Month.

sp.speaker: Hil.
sp.p: I was fatigued with walking in the Garden, and retired to an Arbour to repoſe my ſelf: gueſs what was my Surprize, when I found the dear Perfidious had convey'd himſelf thither before me.

sp.speaker: Squeez.
sp.p: A ſly Dog! My old way again. An Ambuſh is as uſeful in Love as War.

sp.speaker: Hil.
sp.p: At my firſt Entrance, he pretended a Surprize at ſeeing me unexpectedly: but on my queſtioning him how and with what Deſign he had conveyed himſelf there, he immediately threw off the Cloak and confeſſed all: he flew to me, caught me in his Arms with the moſt eager Raptures, and ſwore the moſt violent Love and eternal Conſtancy. I in the greateſt Agony of Rage repelled him with my utmoſt Force; he redoubled his Attacks, I ſlackened my Reſiſtance; he entreated, I raved; he ſighed, I cry'd; he preſſed, I ſwooned; he—

sp.speaker: Squeez.
sp.p: Oh!—I can bear no longer, my Angel! my Paradiſe! my Honey-ſuckle! my Dove! my Darling!

sp.speaker: Hil.
sp.p: What do you mean, Sir?

sp.speaker: Squeez.
sp.p: I mean to eat you up, to ſwallow you down, to ſqueeze you to Pieces.

sp.speaker: Hil.
sp.p: Help there! a Rape, a Rape!

sp.speaker: Sotm.
sp.p: Hey-day! what in the Devil's name is here?—Juſtice Squeezum raviſhing a Woman!

sp.speaker: Hil.
sp.p: Oh! for Heaven's ſake, Sir, aſſiſt a poor forlorn, hapleſs Maid, whom this wicked Man hath treacherouſly ſeduced.

sp.speaker: Squeez.
sp.p: Oh lud!—Oh lud!

sp.speaker: Sotm.
sp.p: Fie upon you, Mr. Squeezum! you who are a Magiſtrate, you who are the Preſerver and Executor of our Laws, thus to be the Breaker of them!

sp.speaker: Squeez.
sp.p: Can'ſt thou accuſe me?

sp.speaker: Hil.
sp.p: You know too well how barbarouſly you have uſed me. For Pity's ſake, Sir, ſecure him; do not let him eſcape, 'till we ſend for a Conſtable. If there be any Law for a Juſtice, I am reſolved to hang him.

sp.speaker: Squeez.
sp.p: Oh lud! what Shame have I brought my ſelf to! that ever I ſhould live to ſee this Day!

sp.speaker: Sotm.
sp.p: If thou hadſt ſtood to thy Bottle like an honeſt Fellow this had never happened, but you muſt go a Whoring with a Pox to you, at your Years too; with theſe ſpindle Shanks, that weezle Face, that Crane's Neck of a Body. Who would have imagined that ſuch an old withered May-pole as thou art ſhould attempt to fall on a Woman? Why, thou wilt be the Diverſion of the whole Town.—Grubſtreet will dine a Month on your Account. Thou wilt be uſhered to Tyburn with more Pomp then Alexander was uſhered into Babylon. Juſtice never triumphs ſo univerſally as at the Execution of one of her own Officers.

sp.speaker: Squeez.
sp.p: Sir, if there be Truth on Earth, I am as innocent—

sp.speaker: Sotm.
sp.p: All the Innocence on Earth will not ſave you—A Man doth not always draw the Rope by the weight of his Sins. Your Innocence will not acquit you in a Court of Juſtice, againſt her Oath; and when you come to the Gallows, it will be vain to plead your Innocence. All's Fiſh that comes to the Net there. The Gallows ſo ſeldom gets its due, that it never parts with what it gets.

sp.speaker: Hil.
sp.p: Can you pretend to Innocence? was not this Gentleman an Eye-witneſs to your Rudeneſs, to the Injuries you offered me?

sp.speaker: Sotm.
sp.p: Ay, ay, I can ſwear to the Rape with as ſafe a Conſcience as I can drink a Glaſs of Wine.

sp.speaker: Squeez.
sp.p: I ſee I am betrayed, I am caught in my own Trap. There is but one way to eſcape, which is the way I have opened to others. [Aſide.] I ſee, Madam, your Deſign is to extort Money from me. I am too well acquainted with the Laws to contend: but I hope you will be reaſonable, for I am poor, very poor, I aſſure you: it is not for Men of my Honeſty to be rich.

sp.speaker: Hil.
sp.p: Sir, if you would give me Millions, it ſhould not ſatisfie my Revenge; you ſhall be hanged for an Example to others.

sp.speaker: Squeez.
sp.p: Here's a cruel Wretch! who prefers my Blood to my Gold, which is almoſt my Blood.

sp.speaker: Sotm.
sp.p: Hey-day! what Vehicle is this? a Vinegar Bottle?—half a Pint, by Jupiter! Why, thou ſneaking Raſcal, can'ſt thou pretend to Honeſty, when this Dram Glaſs hath been found upon thee? Were I thy Judge, or thy Jury, this very ſneaking Vehicle ſhould hang thee, without any other Evidence. But come, ſince you are to be hanged, I'll drink one Bumper to your good Journey to the other World—You will find abundance of your Acquaintance, whom you have ſent before you—And now, I'll go call the Drawer to fetch a Conſtable.

sp.speaker: Squeez.
sp.p: Hold, hold, Sir; for Mercy ſake do not expoſe me ſo—Will nothing content you, Madam?

sp.speaker: Hil.
sp.p: Nothing but the Rigour of the Law. Sir, I beſeech you loſe no Time, but ſend for the Conſtable immediately.

sp.speaker: Squeez.
sp.p: I'll do any thing, I'll conſent to any Terms.

sp.speaker: Hil.
sp.p: The Conſtable! the Conſtable!

sp.speaker: Squeez.
sp.p: Stay, dear Sir! I'll give you a hundred Guineas, I'll do any thing.

sp.speaker: Hil.
sp.p: Remember your vile Commitment of two Gentlemen this Morning—But I will revenge the Injuries of my Friends—Sir, I beſeech you ſend for the Officers.

sp.speaker: Squeez.
sp.p: One is already diſmiſſed from his Confinement, and the other ſhall be diſmiſſed immediately.

sp.speaker: Hil.
sp.p: It is too late.

sp.speaker: Sotm.
sp.p: Hearkee, Sir, will you leave off Whoring, and take to Drinking for the future?

sp.speaker: Squeez.
sp.p: I'll leave them off both.

sp.speaker: Sotm.
sp.p: Then you ſhall be hanged: but if you will commence honeſt Fellow, and get drunk every Day of your Life, I'll intercede with this Lady, that on your acquitting the Gentleman you ſhall be acquitted your ſelf.

sp.speaker: Squeez.
sp.p: I'll do any thing, I'll quit any thing.

sp.speaker: Sotm.
sp.p: Madam, let me perſuade you to be merciful this time to this unfortunate and undutiful Servant of Juſtice.

sp.speaker: Hil.
sp.p: Sir, I can deny you nothing.

sp.speaker: Squeez.
sp.p: Get me a Pen and Ink, I'll ſend an Order to bring him hither, and diſcharge him inſtantly.

sp.speaker: Sotm.
sp.p: Drawer, bring Pen, Ink and Paper, and a Bottle of old Port.

sp.speaker: Squeez.
sp.p: [to Hil.] And could you have had the Conſcience to have ſworn againſt a poor old Man?

sp.speaker: Sotm.
sp.p: Faith! 'twas a little cruel. Could you have had the Heart to ſee him ſwinging like a gibbeted Skeleton? could you have ſerved up ſuch a dry Diſh to Juſtice—The Body of one of her own Children too?—But here's the Paper—Come, Sir, write his Diſcharge and your own.

sp.speaker: Sot.
sp.p: You have managed this Matter ſo well, that I ſhall have an Opinion of your Sex's Underſtanding ever after.

sp.speaker: Hil.
sp.p: Let a Woman alone for a Plot, Mr. Sotmore.

sp.speaker: Sot.
sp.p: Ay, Madam, a Woman that will drink a Bumper. Wine is the Fountain of Thought, and
It is a Queſtion with me, whether Wine hath done more Good, or Phyſick Harm in the World; I would have every Apothecary's Shop in the Town turn'd into a Tavern.

sp.speaker: Hil.
sp.p: I am afraid the more you have of the one, the more you will require of the other.

sp.speaker: Sot.
sp.p: It is their Drugs that debauch our Wine: Wine in it ſelf is as innocent as Water, and Phyſick poiſons both. It is not the Juice of the Grape, but of the Drug, that is pernicious. Let me adviſe you, Madam, leave off your damn'd adulterated Water, your Tea, and take to Wine. It will paint your Face better than Vermilion, and put more Honeſty in your Heart than all the Sermons you can read. I'll introduce you to ſome Clubs of my Acquaintance, a ſet of honeſt Fellows that live in the Clouds of Tobacco, and know no Home but a Tavern.

sp.speaker: Squeez.
sp.p: This Letter, Sir, will produce the Gentleman immediately.

sp.speaker: Sot.
sp.p: Here, Drawer—let this Letter be ſent whither it is directed. Come honeſt Juſtice, our Acquaintance hath an odd Beginning, but we may be very good Companions ſoon: Let us ſit down and expect our Friend in the Manner it becometh us. Remember what you have bargained to do every Day of your Life, and the Obligation ſhall be dated from this Hour. Come, ſit thee down, honeſt Publican, old Juſtice Merchant. [They ſit] Here's a Health to the Propagation of Trade, thy Trade I mean, to the Encreaſe of Whores, and falſe Dice—Thou art a Collector of the Cuſtoms of Sin, and he that would ſin with Impunity, muſt have thy Permit. Come, pledge me, old Boy; if thou leaveſt one Drop in the Glaſs, thou ſhalt go to Goal yet, by this Bottle.

sp.speaker: Squeez.
sp.p: I proteſt, Sir, your Hand is too bountiful, you will overcome me with Wine.

sp.speaker: Sot.
sp.p: Well, and I love to ſee a Magiſtrate drunk; it is a comely Sight: When Juſtice is drunk, ſhe cannot take a Bribe.

sp.speaker: Squeez.
sp.p: Do you not remember how the Athenians puniſhed Drunkenneſs in a Magiſtrate?

sp.speaker: Sot.
sp.p:
And do not I know that we have no ſuch Athenian Law among us? We puniſh Drunkenneſs as well as other Sins, only in the Lower Sort: Drink,
like the Game, was intended for Gentlemen—and no one ſhould get drunk, who cannot go home in a Coach—Come, Madam, it is your Glaſs now.

sp.speaker: Hil.
sp.p: Dear Sir! I beg you would not compel me to it.

sp.speaker: Sot.
sp.p: By this Bottle, but I will, I'll raviſh thee to it before the Juſtice's Face. Come, it will be better for you than Tea, you will not be obliged to ſculk away and take a Dram after this. Come drink the Juſtice's Health, as a Token of Amity; the Juſtice is a good honeſt drunken Fellow. But let me give you ſome wholeſome Advice, [to the Juſtice] leave off fornicating, leave the Girls to the Boys, and ſtand to thy Bottle: It is a Virtue becoming our Years; and don't be too hard on a wild honeſt young Rake. Thou haſt committed a couple of the pretieſt Boys to-day, don't do ſo any more.—Be as ſevere as you pleaſe to Whores and Gameſters, that offer to act without your Licenſe; but if ever you grant a Warrant for a Friend of mine again, you ſhall not only drink the Wine, but eat the Bottle too. Come, here's your Health, in Hopes of your Amendment; thou ſhalt pledge thy own Health in a Bumper—Here, Boy, bring up a Gallon of Wine.

sp.speaker: Squeez.
sp.p: Not a Drop more.

sp.speaker: Sot.
sp.p: A Drop! confound the Name. Come, empty your Glaſs; the Lady is a-dry.

sp.speaker: Squeez.
sp.p: This is worſe than a Priſon.

sp.speaker: Sot.
sp.p: You will get out of this with paying leſs Fees. Drink, I ſay.

sp.speaker: Squeez.
sp.p: Well—ſince I muſt.

sp.speaker: Sot.
sp.p: Come, we'll have a Song in praiſe of Drinking—I'll ſing the Stanza's, and you ſhall bear the Chorus.

lg.l: Let a Set of ſober Aſſes
Rail againſt the Joys of drinking,
While Water, Tea,
And Milk agree,
To ſet cold Brains a thinking:
Power and Wealth,
Beauty, Health,
Wit and Mirth in Wine are crown'd;
Joys abound,
Pleaſure's found,
Only where the Glaſs goes round.

lg.head: II.
lg.l: The Ancient Sects on Happineſs
All differ'd in Opinion,
But wiſer Rules,
Of Modern Schools,
In Wine fix her Dominion:
Power and Wealth, &c.

lg.head: III.
lg.l: Wine gives the Lover Vigour,
It makes glow the Cheeks of Beauty,
Makes Poets write,
And Soldiers fight,
And Friendſhip do its Duty:
Power and Wealth, &c.

lg.head: IV.
lg.l: Wine was the only Helicon,
Whence Poets are long-liv'd ſo;
'Twas no other Main,
Than brisk Champaigne,
Whence Venus was deriv'd too:
Power and Wealth, &c.

lg.head: V.
lg.l: When Heav'n in Pandora's Box
All kind of Ill had ſent us,
In a merry Mood,
A Bottle of Good
Was cork'd up, to content us:
Power and Wealth, &c.

lg.head: VI.
lg.l: All Virtues Wine is Nurſe to,
Of ev'ry Vice Deſtroyer;
Gives Dullards Wit,
Makes juſt the Cit,
Truth forces from the Lawyer:
Power and Wealth, &c.

lg.head: VII.
lg.l: Wine ſets our Joys a flowing,
Our Care and Sorrow drowning.
Who rails at the Bowl,
Is a Turk in's Soul,
And a Chriſtian ne'er ſhould own him:
Power and Wealth, &c.

sp.speaker: Conſt.
sp.p: My Hilaret! my Dear!

sp.speaker: Hil.
sp.p: My Conſtant!

sp.speaker: Sot.
sp.p: Give you Joy, dear Conſtant, of your Liberty.

sp.speaker: Conſt.
sp.p: Thank you, dear Sotmore, to you I am partly obliged for it: Ramble and I will make you Amends▪ we'll give you ſix Nights for this.

sp.speaker: Sot.
sp.p: Where is he?

sp.speaker: Conſt.
sp.p: Very ſafe; be not concerned about him.

sp.speaker: Hil.
sp.p: Well, Sir, ſince our Affair is ended, there is the Purſe you preſented me this Morning. As I have not performed your Expectations one Way, I'll give you what I believe you did not expect—your Money again. It is unopen'd, I aſſure you.

sp.speaker: Squeez.
sp.p: Thou art welcome however.

sp.speaker: Sot.
sp.p: Come, Gentlemen, be pleaſed to take every Man his Chair and his Glaſs; we will dedicate one Hour or two to drinking, I am reſolv'd.

sp.speaker: Squeez.
sp.p: Firſt we will ſacrifice to Juſtice. Mr. Conſtable, do your Duty.

sp.speaker: Staff.
sp.p: Come in there.

div.head: SCENE IX.
div.stage: Squeezum, Hilaret, Sotmore, Conſtant, Staff, Aſſiſtants.
The Aſſiſtants ſeize Conſtant, Hilaret, and Sotmore.

sp.speaker: Squeez.
sp.p: Seize thoſe People in the King's Name—accuſe that Woman and that Man of conſpiring to wear a Rape againſt me.

sp.speaker: Staff.
sp.p: It is in vain to contend, Gentlemen.

sp.speaker: Hil.
sp.p: Oh the Villain!

sp.speaker: Squeez.
sp.p: [to Sot.] The next Letter you extort, Sir, be ſure to examine the Contents.

sp.speaker: Sot.
sp.p: Thou Raſcal! will not even Wine make thee Honeſt.

sp.speaker: Squeez
sp.p: Obſerve, Gentlemen, how abuſive he is; but I'll make an Example of you all: I'll proſecute you to the utmoſt Severity of the Law,—Mr. Conſtable, convey the Priſoners to your Houſe, whence you ſhall have Orders to bring them before a Juſtice.

sp.speaker: Sot.
sp.p: And art thou really in Earneſt?

sp.speaker: Squeez.
sp.p: You ſhall find I am, Sir, to your Coſt.

sp.speaker: Sot.
sp.p: Then I have found one Man with whom I would not drink a Glaſs of Wine.

sp.speaker: Staff.
sp.p: Come, Gentlemen, you know the Way to my Houſe—I am particularly glad to ſee your Honour [to Sotmore] and will accommodate you in the beſt Manner I can.

sp.speaker: Conſt.
sp.p: I am too well acquainted with Misfortune, to repine at any; but how ſhall I bear yours, my Hilaret?

sp.speaker: Hil.
sp.p: The leſs you ſeem to bear, the more you will lighten mine.

sp.speaker: Sot.
sp.p: I muſt give the Juſtice one Wiſh. May Heaven rain Small-Beer upon thee, and may it corrupt thy Body, till it is as putrified as thy Mind.

sp.speaker: Hil.
sp.l: One Bleſſing only may Heav'n leave thy Life,
May it take all things from thee—but thy Wife.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.p: SURE, never Child inherited leſs of a Father's Diſpoſition than mine; her Mother certainly played me foul in the begetting her: I, who have been my whole Life noted for Sobriety, could never have given Being to ſo wild a Creature: I begin to recollect having ſeen a tall Half-pay Officer at my Houſe formerly: Nor do I think the Girl unlike him. I am ſure ſhe hath been ever wild enough, to have had any Officer in the Kingdom for her Father. Nature hath been kind to the Male of all Creatures but Man: The Bull, the Horſe, the Dog are not encumbered even with their own Off-ſpring; that Care falls only to the Females: But Man, when once a gabling Prieſt hath chattered a few miſchievous Words over him, is bound to have and to hold from that Day forward all the Brats his Wife is pleaſed to beſtow on him. Yet I muſt own the Girl hath been ever dutiful to me, till ſhe became acquainted with this curſed Fellow in a Red Coat. Why ſhould Red have ſuch Charms in the Eyes of a Woman? The Roman Senate kept their Armies abroad to prevent their ſharing in their Lands at home, we ſhould do the ſame to prevent their ſharing in our Wives. A tall luſty Fellow ſhall make more work for a Midwife in one Winter at home, than he can for a Surgeon in ten Summers abroad.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.p: Well, any News of my Daughter yet?

sp.speaker: Faith.
sp.p: No, Sir; but there is ſome News from the Secretaries Office, a Mail is arrived from Holland, and you will have the Contents of it in one of the Evening Papers.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.p: Very well! I muſt be patient. I think we have three Mails together now: I am not ſatisfied at all with the Affairs in the North: The Northern Winds have not blown us any Good lately; the Clouds are a little darker in the Eaſt too than I could wiſh them.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.p: Mr. Dabble, good Morrow.

sp.speaker: Dab.
sp.p: Are the Mails come in?

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.p: Juſt arrived.

sp.speaker: Dab.
sp.p: I have not ſlept one wink for reflecting on what you told me laſt Night; perhaps this Dutch Mail may give ſome Inſight into thoſe Affairs. But what ſays the Lying-Poſt?

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.p: I have had no time to read it yet, I wiſh you would. I have only read, The London Journal, the Country Journal, the Weekly Journal, Applebee's Journal, the Britiſh Journal, the Britiſh Gazeteer, the Morning Poſt, the Coffee-Houſe Morning Poſt, the Daily Poſt, the Daily Poſt-Boy, the Daily Journal, the Daily Courant, the Gazette, the Evening Poſt, the Whitehall Evening Poſt, the London Evening Poſt, and the St. James's Evening Poſt. So, if you pleaſe begin the Lying Poſt.

sp.speaker: Dab.
sp.p: [reads.] Moſcow, January the fifth. 'We learn from Conſtantinople, that Affairs continue ſtill in the ſame doubtful way, it is not yet known what Courſe our Court will take. The Empreſs having been ſlightly indiſpoſed the other Day took the Air in her own Coach, and returned ſo well recovered, that ſhe eat a very hearty Supper.'—

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.p: Hum—there is no mention of the Supper in any other Papers.

sp.speaker: Dab.
sp.p: Berlin, January the 20th. 'We hear daily Murmurs here concerning certain Meaſures taken by a certain Northern Potentate; but cannot certainly learn either who that Potentate is, or what are the Meaſures which he hath taken—mean time we are well aſſured that Time will bring them all to light.'

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.p: Pray read that laſt over again.

sp.speaker: Dab.
sp.p: 'Mean time, we are well aſſured that Time will bring them all to light.'

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.p: Hum! hum!

sp.speaker: Dab.
sp.p: Marſeilles, January the 18th. 'The Affairs in regard to Italy, continue ſtill in the ſame uncertain Condition.'

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.p: Hum.

sp.speaker: Dab.
sp.p: 'The Talk of a large Embarkation ſtill runs high.'

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.p: Hum.

sp.speaker: Dab.
sp.p: 'The Spaniards continue ſtill encamped near Barcelona.'

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.p: Hum! [Shakes his Head.]

sp.speaker: Dab.
sp.p: 'And every thing ſeems tending to a Rupture—mean time we expect the Return of a Courier from Vienna, who 'tis generally expected will bring the News of a general Pacification.'

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.p: All is well again!

sp.speaker: Dab.
sp.p: I like this, and ſome other Papers, who diſappoint you with good News. Where the beginning of a Paragraph threatens you with War, and the latter part of it enſures you Peace.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.p: Pleaſe to read on—

sp.speaker: Dab.
sp.p: 'However, notwithſtanding theſe Aſſurances, 'tis doubted by moſt People, whether the ſaid Courier will not rather bring a Confirmation of the War; but this is all gueſs-work, and till ſuch time as we ſee an actual Hoſtility committed, we muſt leave our Readers in the ſame uncertain State we found them.'

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.p: Hum! There is no Certainty to be come at, I find; it may be either Peace or War.

sp.speaker: Dab.
sp.p: Tho' were I to lay a Wager, I ſhould chuſe War; for, if you obſerve, we are twice aſſured of that, whereas we have only one Affirmation on the ſide of Peace—but ſtay, perhaps the next Paragraph which is dated from Fontain-bleau may decide the Queſtion. 'Fontain-bleau, January 23, Yeſterday his Majeſty went a Hunting, to-day he hears an Opera, and tomorrow he hears Maſs.'

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.p: I don't like that; hearing Maſs is ſeldom the Forerunner of good News.

sp.speaker: Dab.
sp.p: ' It is obſervable that Cardinal Fleury'—

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.p: Ay, now for it.

sp.speaker: Dab.
sp.p: 'It is obſervable that Cardinal Fleury hath for ſeveral Days laſt paſt been in cloſe Conference with the Miniſter of a certain State, which cauſes various Speculations; but as we do not know what was the Matter in Debate, we cannot ſay what may be the Conſequence thereof. Mean time we cannot help obſerving, that it hath occaſioned ſome People to put on very ſerene Looks, who had worn cloudy ones for ſome time before: Some imagine on comparing this with the News from Marſeilles, that a War will be unavoidable—others, who are more peaceably inclined, are as ſtrenuous Advocates on the other ſide—We muſt refer the whole to the Determination of Time, that great Judge in worldly Affairs, who never fails with his two-edged Scithe to mow down the Weeds, which ſhadow over the ſecret Counſels of State, and lay them open to the naked Eye of the diſcerning Politician.'

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.p: Shall I beg to hear that over again?

sp.speaker: Dab.
sp.p: [reads.] 'We muſt refer the whole to the Determination,' &c.

sp.speaker: Faith.
sp.p: Oh, Sir! Cloris hath brought the ſtrangeſt News of my young Miſtreſs.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.p: Don't interrupt us—Blockhead.

sp.speaker: Faith.
sp.p: If you loſe a Moment ſhe may be loſt for ever.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.p: Sirrah! Peace.

sp.speaker: Faith.
sp.p: Sir, my young Miſtreſs, Miſs Hilaret, will be undone, ruined, hanged, if you do not aſſiſt her; ſhe's taken up for a Rape—Oh! my poor young Lady! the ſweeteſt, beſt-temper'd Lady ſure that ever was born. Oh! that ever I ſhould ſee the Day! And can you ſit here, Sir, reading a parcel of damn'd confounded lying Nonſenſe, and not go to your Daughter's Aſſiſtance?

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.p: Sure the Fellow is poſſeſſed.

sp.speaker: Faith.
sp.p: Sir, your Daughter is poſſeſſed—poſſeſſed by Conſtables—ſhe is taken up for a Rape.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.p: My Daughter taken up for a Rape!

sp.speaker: Faith.
sp.p: Yes, Sir, for Raviſhing a Juſtice of Peace.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.p: Sure ſome Accident hath touched the Fellow's Brain.

sp.speaker: Faith.
sp.p: Ay, Sir, and it would touch yours too, if you had a Grain of Humanity in you.—Oh! that I ſhould live to ſee my poor young Lady in ſuch a Misfortune.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.p: A Woman taken up for a Rape—it is impoſſible.

sp.speaker: Faith.
sp.p: They may ſwear it tho' for all that—I know her to be as modeſt a good young Lady as any in the Kingdom; but what will not a ſet of Rogues ſwear. Sir, I liv'd with Squeezum before I liv'd with you; and know him to be as great a Villain as any in the Kingdom. Do, good Sir, come but with me to Juſtice Worthy's, if you do not find your Daughter there, turn me away for a Vagabond.

sp.speaker: Dab.
sp.p: I do remember, Neighbour Politick, to have ſeen in ſome News-Paper a Story not very different from this.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.p: Nay, if you have ſeen it in a News-Paper, it may probably have ſome Truth in it; ſo Neighbour Dabble you will excuſe me, I will meet you within an Hour at the Coffee-houſe, and there we will confer farther.

sp.speaker: Wor.
sp.p: Sure Modeſty is quite baniſhed from the Age we live in. There was a time when Virtue carried ſomething of a divine Awe with it, which no one durſt attack; but now the Inſolence of our Youth is ſuch, no Woman dare walk the Streets but thoſe who do it for Bread.

sp.speaker: Iſa.
sp.p: And yet our Laws, Brother Worthy, are as rigorous as thoſe of other Countries, and as well executed.

sp.speaker: Wor.
sp.p: That I wiſh they were; but Golden Sands too often clog the Wheels of Juſtice, and obſtruct her Courſe: The very Riches which were the greateſt Evidence of his Villany, have too often declared the Guilty innocent; and Gold hath been found to cut a Halter ſurer than the ſharpeſt Steel.

sp.speaker: Iſa.
sp.p: Well, I am reſolved to take care how I venture a ſtep again after it is dark: I find the Sun is the only Guard to us Women; for however chaſte the Moon may be in her ſelf, ſhe takes but very little care of ours.

sp.speaker: Wor.
sp.p: But could the Villain be very rude?

sp.speaker: Iſa.
sp.p: As rude as ſo ſhort a time would permit. I would have given all I was worth in the World, to have been here; but ſince I eſcaped, let us forget it.

sp.speaker: Wor.
sp.p: Forget! By Heaven it ſhocks me, that we who boaſt as wholſome Laws as any Kingdom upon Earth, ſhould by the Roguery of ſome of their Executors loſe all their Benefit. I long to ſee the time when here, as in Holland, the Traveller may walk unmoleſted, and carry his Riches openly with him.

sp.speaker: Squeez.
sp.p: Mr. Worthy, your humble Servant. I come to wait on you on the ſtrangeſt Piece of Buſineſs. We are brought to a fine Paſs indeed, when Magiſtrates ſhall not be ſafe; we are like to protect others, when we cannot protect our ſelves.

sp.speaker: Wor.
sp.p: What is the occaſion of all this Paſſion, Mr. Squeezum?

sp.speaker: Squeez.
sp.p: Occaſion! I have ſcarce Power to tell you. I have diſcovered one of the moſt damnable Conſpiracies, that hath been invented ſince the Gunpowder-Treaſon Plot.

sp.speaker: Wor.
sp.p: Nothing againſt the Government, I hope.

sp.speaker: Squeez.
sp.p: Marry, but it is; for that which is againſt the Officers of the Government, is againſt the Government. In ſhort, Sir, it is a Conſpiracy againſt me, againſt my ſelf. What do you think, Brother Worthy, but that moved and ſeduced by the Inſtigation of the Devil, a vile Woman hath conſpired to ſwear a Rape againſt me?

sp.speaker: Wor.
sp.p: A Rape againſt you! fooliſh Jade! Why your very Face would acquit you—you have Innocence in your Looks, Brother Squeezum.

sp.speaker: Squeez.
sp.p: I hope my Character will acquit me againſt ſuch an Accuſation.

sp.speaker: Wor.
sp.p: I think it ought; a Man whoſe Character would not, is very unfit for that honourable Commiſſion you bear.

sp.speaker: Squeez.
sp.p: True! theſe Slurs reflect on us all. The accuſing a Member, is accuſing the Body. We ſhould conſider it may be our own caſe. We ſhould ſtand by one another, as the Lawyers do. I hope, Brother, you will ſhew me extraordinary Juſtice; and I aſſure you, ſhould any Affair of yours come before me, my Partiality ſhall lean on your ſide.

sp.speaker: Wor.
sp.p: Partiality, Sir! I hope no Cauſe of mine will ever require it. I aſſure you, I ſhall do you the ſtricteſt Juſtice; I believe you will not need more.

sp.speaker: Squeez.
sp.p: Sir, my Caſe needs no more; but I think it incumbent on us all, to diſcountenance any Proſecution of our ſelves on any Account whatſoever.

sp.speaker: Wor.
sp.p: To diſcountenance it by the Innocence of our Lives, is indeed laudable, but no farther. It is a curſed Law, which exempts the Maker, or the Executor of it, from its Penalty.

sp.speaker: Squeez.
sp.p: Truly, Brother Worthy, I think the Makers of Laws, and the Executors of them, ſhould be free of them; as Authors and Actors are free of the Playhouſe.

sp.speaker: Wor.
sp.p: You are ludicrous, Mr. Squeezum. But let me tell you, he is the greateſt of Villains, who hath the Impudence to hold the Sword of Juſtice, while he deſerves its Edge.

sp.speaker: Squeez.
sp.p: And let me tell you, Brother Worthy, he is the greateſt of Fools, who holds the Sword of Juſtice, and hurts himſelf with it.

sp.speaker: Iſa.
sp.p: Brother, your Servant; my Preſence will be very little neceſſary at this Tryal.

div.head: SCENE VII.
div.stage: Worthy, Squeezum, Conſtant, Hilaret, Staff, Sotmore, Brazencourt, Fireball, three Aſſiſtants.

sp.speaker: Squeez.
sp.p: But here come the Priſoners—Brother Worthy, this is the Woman whom I accuſe of this deteſtable Fact;—the Manner of it was this. I received a Letter in an unknown Hand, appointing me to meet at a Tavern, which out of pure Good-nature I comply'd with; and upon my Arrival found that Woman there alone, who after a ſhort Diſcourſe laid hold of me and bawl'd out, on which that Man there entered, and both threaten'd me, that unleſs I immediately diſcharged that Man [points to Conſt.] with another whom I had committed for notorious Crimes, that the Woman ſhould ſwear a Rape againſt me—This I am ready to ſwear.—

sp.speaker: 1. 2. 3. Aſſ.
sp.p: And we are ready to ſwear.

sp.speaker: Wor.
sp.p: What do you ſay, young Woman, to this? You do not look like one whom I ſhould ſuſpect of ſuch a Behaviour.

sp.speaker: Hil.
sp.p: That I did threaten him, as he ſays, indeed I confeſs.

sp.speaker: Wor.
sp.p: But did he attempt any ſuch thing?

sp.speaker: Hil.
sp.p: I can't ſay he did, but—

sp.speaker: Squeez.
sp.p: Do you hear this, Brother Worthy? I think you have nothing to do but to make her Mittimus.

sp.speaker: Wor.
sp.p: And for what Reaſon did you offer this?

sp.speaker: Hil.
sp.p: I offer'd it only to frighten him to the Diſcharge of two Gentlemen, whom he had villanouſly committed to the Cuſtody of that Conſtable.

sp.speaker: Wor.
sp.p: For what Crimes do they ſtand committed, Mr. Conſtable?

sp.speaker: Staff.
sp.p: For two Rapes, an't pleaſe your Worſhip.

sp.speaker: Hil.
sp.p: One of them on my Account—tho' I never ſwore the leaſt thing againſt him.

sp.speaker: Wor.
sp.p: On your Account,—I begin to be afraid he was unjuſtly committed indeed.

sp.speaker: Squeez.
sp.p: Now Sir, we ſhall proceed to blacken a little the Character of this Woman. Call Mr. Brazencourt; Mr. Brazencourt, what do you know of this fine Lady?

sp.speaker: Brazen.
sp.p: I know nothing more of her, than that I kept her half a Year.

sp.speaker: Wor.
sp.p: Kept her!—in what Capacity did you keep her?

sp.speaker: Brazen.
sp.p: In the Capacity of a Whore, till I was obliged to turn her off, for ſtealing four of my Shirts, two pair of Stockings, and my Common-prayer Book.

sp.speaker: Squeez.
sp.p: Call Captain Fireball.

sp.speaker: Wor.
sp.p: Captain Fireball, pray, do you know any Harm of that Perſon there?

sp.speaker: Fire.
sp.p: Harm of her! ay, and ſo doth my Surgeon too. She came to me from Major Brazencourt. I kept her two Months.

sp.speaker: Hil.
sp.p: Sir, I beſeech you hear me.

sp.speaker: Wor.
sp.p: By and by. You muſt not interrupt them—Go on. Did you loſe any thing by her too?

sp.speaker: Fire.
sp.p: No, but I got ſomething by her, which made my Surgeon get ſomething by me—I love to expreſs my ſelf in modeſt Terms, but I believe you all know what I mean.

sp.speaker: Conſtant.
sp.p: Damnation!

sp.speaker: Squeez.
sp.p: Call Mr. Drury. We ſhall blacken her farther preſently.

sp.speaker: Wor.
sp.p: Indeed, you need not; let us hear no more; for her ſake, I will never put Confidence in an innocent Countenance again.—Well, Woman, can you ſay any thing for your ſelf?

sp.speaker: Hil.
sp.p: Oh! that I could hide my ſelf for ever from the World, and never from this Hour behold the Sun again.

sp.speaker: Wor.
sp.p: Indeed but you ſhall, Madam, and be beheld by others too.

sp.speaker: Conſt.
sp.p: Come to my Boſom, thou deareſt, ſweeteſt, lovelieſt, hide thy Sorrows there—Death only ſhall tear thee from my Arms again. Death, Hell it ſelf cannot have a Torment equal to ſeeing one Tear of thine.

sp.speaker: Sot.
sp.p: Heark'e, Juſtice, I believe thou art honeſter than thy Brother; I am ſure thou canſt not be a greater Rogue: If thou wilt act the right Part, acquit us, and ſend that Villain to Priſon.

div.head: SCENE VIII.
div.stage: Worthy, Squeezum, Conſtant, Hilaret, Sotmore, Staff, Conſtable, Aſſiſtants, Politick, Faithful, Cloris.

sp.speaker: Faith.
sp.p: Now, Sir, will you believe your own Eyes?—Is not that your own Daughter?

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.p: It is indeed. O my unfortunate Child—

sp.speaker: Wor.
sp.p: Mr. Politick, your humble Servant—I will but commit this Woman to Goal, and then I will be at your Command.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.p: Sir, you ſhall not be my humble Servant, nor will I be yours; and if you commit my Daughter to Priſon, you are the worſt of Turks.

sp.speaker: Wor.
sp.p: Your Daughter, Sir?

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.p: Yes, Sir, my Daughter, Sir.

sp.speaker: Hil.
sp.p: Oh! my Father!

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.p: My poor Child!—That ever I ſhould live to ſee thee in ſuch a Misfortune!

sp.speaker: Wor.
sp.p: Is it poſſible, Mr. Politick, that this young Lady is your Daughter?

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.p: Yes, Sir, it is as poſſible, as that the Turks may come into our Part of Europe; and I wiſh this may not be as ſure as that.

div.head: SCENE IX.
div.stage: Worthy, Squeezum, Conſtant, Hilaret, Staff, Conſtables, Aſſiſtants, Politick, Faithful, Sotmore, Cloris, Ramble, Mrs. Squeezum, Quill.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Squeez.
sp.p: Where is this Glory of the Bench, this Gallant Juſtice? this Terror and Example of Sin? Do you know this Hand, Sir? Did you write this Aſſignation? You are a noble Gentleman truly, to make an Appointment with a fine Lady, and then bring her before a Magiſtrate.

sp.speaker: Squeez.
sp.p: O my malignat Stars!

sp.speaker: Wor.
sp.p: Mrs. Squeezum, what is the matter?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Squeez.
sp.p: You Mr. Worthy, I am ſure will pity one who hath the Misfortune to be married to a Man, who is as much a Scandal to the Commiſſion he bears, as you are an Honour to it; my Conſcience hath been too long burthened with conniving at his Rogueries. He, Sir, he alone is guilty, and every one whom he hath accuſed is innocent.

sp.speaker: Wor.
sp.p: I know not what to think.

sp.speaker: Ramb.
sp.p:
Sir, that Fellow there, that Butcher of Juſtice, is the greateſt Villain that ever was born—Being a little frolickſome laſt Night with this Lady, that Conſtable ſeiz'd us. 'Tis to me ſhe is indebted
for all this Trouble; tho' Mr. Conſtable may claim ſome Share, in not ſuffering us to depart at her Deſire.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Squeez.
sp.p: And Mr. Juſtice may claim a little, who committed you to the Conſtable's Houſe without any Evidence, or even Accuſation.

sp.speaker: Ramb.
sp.p: That he might extort two hundred Pounds, for which Sum he offered to compromiſe the Matter.

sp.speaker: Squeez.
sp.p: Heark'e, Madam, I ſhall be obliged to commit you to Bedlam.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Squeez.
sp.p: No, Sir, I ſhall prevent you in that, as well as in your other Deſigns; your Plot with Mr. Quill, which the whole World ſhall know; you ſhall be divorced, Sir, tho' not the Way you deſire.

sp.speaker: Squeez.
sp.p: Sir, I beſeech you to hear no more.

sp.speaker: Wor.
sp.p: That, Sir, I cannot grant.

sp.speaker: Ramb.
sp.p: Sir, I deſire that you would read that Letter, which he ſent to this young Lady whom he hath accuſed.

sp.speaker: Wor.
sp.p: [Reads.] 'My little Honey-ſuckle, I will meet you within this half Hour at the Eagle. I hope after what you have received from me to-day, you will not diſappoint yours till then and everafter.'—
Did you write this Letter, Mr. Squeezum?

sp.speaker: Squeez.
sp.p: No, Sir, as I am ready to ſwear.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Squeez.
sp.p: Sir, I will ſwear it to be his Hand—

sp.speaker: Faith.
sp.p: And ſo will I—I lived with him a Twelvemonth, and therefore ſhould know it.

sp.speaker: Quill.
sp.p: And I carried it to the Lady.

sp.speaker: Sot.
sp.p: Come, come, Juſtice, thou haſt Proof enough of her Innocence. I will give you the Word of a Man of Honour, which is more than the Oaths of twenty ſuch Scoundrels as theſe, that ſhe never intended more than to frighten him to the Acquittal of Captain Conſtant here, whom he had unjuſtly committed.

sp.speaker: Conſt.
sp.p: And offered to acquit for a Sum of Money.

sp.speaker: Wor.
sp.p: Captain Conſtant! is your Name Conſtant, Sir?

sp.speaker: Conſt.
sp.p: At your Service.

sp.speaker: Wor.
sp.p: Deſire my Siſter to walk hither—I am more obliged to you than you know

sp.speaker: Squeez.
sp.p: Come, Sir, this is only loſing Time—I want the Mittimus.

div.head: SCENE X.
div.stage: Worthy, Squeezum, Ramble, Conſtant, Sotmore, Hilaret, Politick, Mrs. Squeezum, Quill, Staff, Faithful, &c. Iſabella.

sp.speaker: Wor.
sp.p: Siſter, do you know this Gentleman?

sp.speaker: Iſa.
sp.p: Captain Conſtant! It is happy for me that I do—I thank you, Sir, for your generous Reſcue laſt Night, which my Fright at that time prevented my acknowledging.

sp.speaker: Conſt.
sp.p: And was it you, Madam?—

sp.speaker: Ramb.
sp.p: My Iſabella!

sp.speaker: Iſa.
sp.p: Ha!—it is, it is my Ramble—

sp.speaker: Ramb.
sp.p: My Touch deceives me not, it is my charming She, once more reſtored to my deſpairing Hopes.

sp.speaker: Iſa.
sp.p: What lucky Stars can have contrived this Interview?

sp.speaker: Ramb.
sp.p: Very lucky Stars they appear now; but they had a confounded ugly Aſpect ſome time ago.

sp.speaker: Iſa.
sp.p: Surprizing! Brother, let that Fellow be ſecured. He was the Perſon from whoſe Hands this Gentleman delivered me.

sp.speaker: Quill.
sp.p: I hope your Worſhip will forgive me; but I hir'd theſe two Men, by my Maſter's Command, to be Evidences for him.

sp.speaker: Wor.
sp.p: Surprizing Villany!—ſecure them inſtantly. And particularly that Juſtice,—whom I ſhall no longer treat as a Gentleman, but as his Villany hath merited—Conſtable, I charge you with them all—and let them be kept below in the Parlour, whither I will come immediately and ſign their Commitment.

sp.speaker: Squeez.
sp.p: Sir, you ſhall wiſh you had dealt more favourably with me.

sp.speaker: Wor.
sp.p: Sir, your Threatnings will not terrifie me.

sp.speaker: Faith.
sp.p: Come, Gentlemen, we'll be your Safe-guard.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Squeez.
sp.p: I'll follow thee, like thy evil Genius, till I have brought thee to that Juſtice thou deſerveſt.

div.head: SCENE the Laſt.
div.stage:
Worthy, Ramble, Con
•• ant, Sotmore, Hilaret, Iſabella, Politick.

sp.speaker: Ramb.
sp.p: My dear Iſabella, I am ſo overjoyed at this unexpected Meeting, that I do not ask for the Safety of our Treaſure. Since the Sea hath refunded Iſabella, let it take the Jewels.

sp.speaker: Iſa.
sp.p: The Sea hath been even kinder than your Wiſh, it hath return'd you both.

sp.speaker: Ramb.
sp.p: I ſhould have ſoon forgotten that Loſs, in having Iſabella; yet for her ſake, the Teaſure is welcome too.

sp.speaker: Wor.
sp.p: Mr. Politick, I am heartily concerned at this Misfortune which hath befallen your Daughter.

sp.speaker: Ramb.
sp.p: Mr. Politick!—By Heavens, his Features are the ſame. Had you not a Son, Sir, once?

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.p: Yes, Sir, I had; but I turn'd him out of Doors, and believe he was hanged long ago.

sp.speaker: Ramb.
sp.p: Then I am his Ghoſt, juſt arrived from the Indies. When you turn'd me out of Doors, I got admitted into the Eaſt-India Company's Service; I changed my Name in order to eſcape your Diſcovery—and I hope you will now give us both your Bleſſing.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.p: And are you really that wild Follow my Son?

sp.speaker: Ramb.
sp.p: I am that very identical wild Perſon, I aſſure you.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.p: I don't know whether I'll give you my Bleſſing or no, till I ſee how you are married.

sp.speaker: Wor.
sp.p: Mr. Politick, I rejoice in the Union of our Families; this Lady, your Son's Wife, is my Siſter—and if fourſcore thouſand Pounds can make the Match agreeable to you, it will be ſo.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.p: Hath the wild Rogue made his Fortune at laſt! Well, Son, I give you my Bleſſing; and my dear Daughter I give you Joy, and I hope the Boy will give it you, ay, and laſting conſtant Joy—If he doth not make you a good Husband, I'll not own him; if he doth not make you bleſſed, he ſhall have no Bleſſing of mine.

sp.speaker: Iſa.
sp.p: Sir, I doubt him not.

sp.speaker: Ramb.
sp.p: Well, Father, I have nothing more to ask of you, but in Favour of my Friend Captain Conſtant, whoſe Love I am certain will compleat the Happineſs of my Siſter.

sp.speaker: Wor.
sp.p: I think I have never been witneſs to ſuch a Complication of Villany. Sir, [to Conſtant] I aſſure you, and all of you, you ſhall have ſufficient Reparaton for the Injuries you have ſuffer'd. And Sir, by the Characters which I have had from my Siſter of that Gentleman, I do not think your Daughter can be better diſpoſed of, let the Difference of Fortune be what it pleaſe.

sp.speaker: Ramb.
sp.p: Beſides, tho' his Eſtate be not equal now, it may become ſo; for no Man hath a better Inſight into Politicks.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.p: Nay, if his Studies bend that Way, no Man indeed can tell to what his Eſtate may come—Had I known this ſooner, my Doors ſhould never have been ſhut againſt him. Sir, I ſhall be glad to confabulate with you at my Houſe—and if you ſhould ſet your Heart on my Daughter, I do not believe I ſhall do any thing to break it.

sp.speaker: Ramb.
sp.p: Nay, Sir, there is no Hour like the Preſent: This Hour hath proved lucky to your Family—Give me leave to preſent your Daughter to one whom if ſhe deſerves, I ſhall be proud of calling her Siſter.

sp.speaker: Conſt.
sp.p: Ramble, you have crown'd my Obligations with a Gift, far dearer than the Earth could prove.

sp.speaker: Hil.
sp.p:
I only wiſh you may always think ſo, Captain. And now, Pappa, I hope you will pardon this Night's Sally, to both me and poor Cloris; we have been already
ſufficiently puniſhed; and ſince the Event is happpy, imitate in this one thing the Turks, and conſider it favourably, as it hath been proſperous.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.p: The Turks! I wiſh you were better acquainted with them than in Romances; I hope that Gentleman will take care to inſtruct you in publick Affairs.—Well Jack [to Ramble] I long to have ſome Communication with you about the Affairs of the Indies, and the Poſture of our Trade there—I hope you left the Great Mogul in good Health—

sp.speaker: Ramb.
sp.p: Very ſlightly indiſpoſed of a Cold at my Departure.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.p: I heartily forgive you all: So let me ſee you all embrace one another—This is the Comfort of Age, Mr. Worthy.

sp.speaker: Sot.
sp.p: Let me embrace you all together—I have found this Day two good Women—and they have fallen to the Share of my Friends—and I will get drunk this Night, if the Spirit of Wine will do it—I'll drink to your Happineſs, while you are enjoying it—While you are taſting the Joys of Venus, I will ſwallow down the Delights of Bacchus—I deſpair of either of your Company this Month yet—but the Juſtice ſhall celebrate this Night with me—Come, honeſt Juſtice—I have found one honeſt Juſtice too—

sp.speaker: Wor.
sp.p: Really, Sir, I think you have ſufficiently celebrated already—

sp.speaker: Sot.
sp.p: No, but I have not—and you, Sir, will be drunk at your Children's Wedding-Night.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.p: I never drink any thing but Coffee, Sir.

sp.speaker: Sot.
sp.p: Damn your Coffee—

sp.speaker: Ramb.
sp.p: Sotmore, thou ſhalt have Juſtice—Mr. Worthy, I aſſure you, notwithſtanding this Humour, the World hath not an honeſter Man.

sp.speaker: Wor.
sp.p:
It is pity he ſhould beſot himſelf ſo. Your Character of him encourages me to employ ſome Labour in adviſing him, to quit ſo beaſtly a Pleaſure.—Come Gentlemen, I deſire you would celebrate this Day at my Houſe to-morrow. I will proceed to take
all poſſible Meaſures to your receiving Satisfaction for your Injuries, and making publick Example of ſo great a Villain: for the Crimes of a Magiſtrate give the greateſt Sanction to Sin.
sp.l: No Reverence that Church or State attends,
Whoſe Laws the Prieſt or Magiſtrate offends.
